Let's have a look at the record of those opposite on the issue of health. Under the Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison Liberal-National government, Queenslanders have lost out on health big time. We know that Mr Turnbull successfully implemented his GP tax, with Australians now paying around $4 more out of their own pocket every time they go to the doctor. Patients are now over $12 more out of pocket when they need to see a specialist. And now we see more vicious, cruel cuts to the country's health budget. Let's just go through those: $715 million ripped out of hospitals around the country, with $160 million ripped out of Queensland hospitals. That's the equivalent of slashing the jobs of 1,435 nurses in our state. Brisbane's dedicated children's hospital, Lady Cilento, has suffered a $6.5 million cut. The Metro North health district has lost $32 million under the Liberal-Nationals.

Let's have a look at where some of that's coming from: $14.3 million from the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital, $7.7 million from the Prince Charles Hospital at Chermside and $2.9 million from the Caboolture Hospital. We learnt during the Longman by-election recently just how locals felt about that. For the Redcliffe Hospital there has been a $4.2 million funding cut. That's the equivalent of 37 fewer nurses working at Redcliffe Hospital. What's worse is that the Queensland government is still waiting for the Liberal-National federal government to pay up the $780 million owed for procedures delivered as far back as 2014; $128 million of that is activity funding owed to Metro North Hospitals like Redcliffe.

While these bills were going unpaid by this governmentâ€”while these health cuts were happeningâ€”what did the local Liberal member, Mr Luke Howarth, do or say? Nothingâ€”not a thing. Did he stand up for his community on health? No. Did he stand up for local seniors, families and children who use the Redcliffe Hospital, the Prince Charles Hospital, the RBWH or Lady Cilento? No, no, no and no. Did he stand up in Canberra and say, 'Look, guys: we probably should be paying our bills'? No, he did not, and on that matter I want to emphasise the fact that this federal government has had form in not paying to Queensland the money that is due for funding for services and procedures already delivered by the Queensland hospital system. Under Mr Turnbull the federal government spent 51 weeks arguing over what was undisputed fundingâ€”and there is still funding missing, as I've indicated.

To go back to late last year, the Queensland health minister, Mr Miles, had to write to his federal counterpart to seek urgent action over a funding black hole that would blow out to almost a billion dollars by 2019. I used to think coalition governments would respect the fact that you have to pay your bills on time but, obviously, that is now out the window.

Let's return to Mr Howarth and what he did. If we look further at Mr Howarth's record on other matters we can see that he also stayed quiet while his government prioritised banks over schools. He stayed quiet while local workers struggled with cuts to their penalty rates. And he has said nothing about how energy prices and poor internet access have been hurting small businesses and households in his electorate. Then, during the August sittings of parliament, it all became clear: the Liberal member for Petrie was too busy plotting the overthrow of Mr Turnbull. He was too busy plotting the uprising of his mate in the electorate next door, the federal member for Dickson, Mr Dutton. And, yes, as the news of the appalling events of the last sittings leaked out it emerged that it was Mr Howarth who was planning to call for Mr Turnbull's resignation, despite having said in April that he would not support a leadership challenge. So Mr Howarth cannot be taken at his word, and, given his actions in the leadership spill, I can't imagine that the Petrie electorate is now on the top of new Prime Minister Morrison's priority list.

But the people in the Petrie electorate are at the top of Corinne Mulholland's priority list. As I said, she is our candidate for the federal seat of Petrie. Restoring the Liberal-National cuts to health and education are absolutely on top of Labor's priority list. Locals know that Redcliffe Hospital needs and deserves a Medicare-subsidised MRI machine. Labor has a proud record on MRI licences, granting 238 of them when we were last in government. Madam Acting Deputy President Kitching, it's probably no surprise to you that, in the last five years of this Liberal-National government, only five MRI licences have been granted.

Australians deserve better when it comes to health. Queenslanders deserve better when it comes to our local hospitals. Patients visiting Redcliffe Hospital deserve access to an MRI, without having to pay to go private or to travel long distances. I encourage listeners to visit www.RedcliffeMRI.com and add their voices to the hundreds who have already signed the petition and joined our campaign. Together we can protect and grow the Redcliffe Hospital with a new MRI licence, and together we can show the chaotic, divided Liberal-Nationals the door and elect a new representative for the Petrie electorateâ€”a representative who listens and cares; a representative who fights for the needs of locals, rather than their own self-interest and plotting and scheming; and a representative who works as part of a team.

We need a federal Labor government now more than ever to restore stability and fairness to government and to bring back equality and the fair go. This is what Labor stands for and this is what Corinne Mulholland is fighting for in Petrie. We know that MRIs are a hugely important part of the medical system at the moment. I note that there has been a recent Senate report into the use of MRI in Australia. I also note that it has been highlighted that under our current system MRI machines are less likely to be found in less affluent suburbs than in suburbs with more affluent residents. So, there is a need for this campaign to succeed. There is a need for residents in the Redcliffe area to have access to this lifesaving technology. I encourage everybody to get on board with this campaign. It is such a worthwhile one and is illustrative of the efforts of our campaign in the Petrie electorate.
Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

Senator SIEWERT (Western Australiaâ€”Australian Greens Whip) (13:03): Today I rise to speak on Aboriginal deaths in custody. I planned to make this statement before the horrible, tragic deaths of two Aboriginal boys in Perth on Monday afternoon. My heart goes out to their families and their community. Their community is in deep mourning and grief. This tragedy should never have happened. It has been treated as 'deaths in police presence' or, as others are calling it, 'deaths in custody'.

Recently, TheGuardian published their Deaths inside database. The database is the product of TheGuardian's own investigations into deaths in custody since the completion of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in 1991, which exposed the number of lives lost in a system that continues to fail our First Nations peoples. As TheGuardian points out, one of the 339 recommendations of the royal commission was to establish a national program implemented by The Australian Institute of Criminology to track and report on further deaths in custody. The intention was to ensure that these issues remain firmly within the public view, yet, when TheGuardianwent searching for the data, it could not be found.

After the arduous task of requesting reports from each state and territory and manually collating the data, plus analysing over 460 coronial reports from the past decade, TheGuardian has highlighted what successive governments have failed to addressâ€”that following the completion of the royal commission there have been a further 407 deaths in custody of First Nations people. We already know that First Nations peoples are disproportionately represented in our prisons. As of 30 June 2017 there were 11,307 prisoners who identified as First Nations peoples, representing 27 per cent of the total prison populationâ€”a travesty in the first place. TheGuardian's analysis of 463 cases between 2010 and 2015 found 31.5 per cent of the deaths in custody involved an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person. This is despite First Nations people representing only 3.3 per cent of the Australian population. So not only are they disproportionately represented in our prisons but they are also more likely to die while in the custody of our police and corrective services. This is our national shame.

The
Guardian identified 147 cases of First Nations peoples dying while in custody over the past decade. There have been four deaths this year alone. Of the 147 people in these cases, more than half had not yet been convicted of their alleged crime, were being held in protective custody or were being pursued by police, typically for minor crimes, such as public intoxication, that carry sentences of less than five years. These people subsequently paid with their lives. This includes teenagers as young as 13 years old.

If you look more deeply into the database of the deaths, you will discover some devastating statistics. In 46 of the cases, it was found that the authorities failed to follow correct procedures. In 35 cases, the person who passed was injured, leading to death, whilst being pursued or placed into custody. Thirty per cent of the cases involved authorities providing an insufficient level of medical care, ultimately resulting in death. Thirty-eight per cent of the cases involved people with a mental health condition or cognitive impairment. Forty-five per cent of the deaths were the result of medical issues, many of which involved conditions that would normally be easily treatable. As I said, this is our national shame.

Going through the coronial reports, TheGuardian's report highlighted instances of insufficient pain management practices, incorrect treatment and medical care, and insensitive treatment of family and loved ones. In one instance, police ignored requests for heart medication following the arrest of a 50-year-old man in South Australia, resulting in his becoming unresponsive and unable to be revived. In another instance there were accusations corrective services guards ignored the pleas of a diabetic and schizophrenic man who claimed he could not breathe after being issued with a sedative. The guards then incorrectly applied resuscitation techniques. In yet another instance a man experienced respiratory failure while being pinned down, handcuffed and tranquilised in hospital. He arrived at the hospital voluntarily seeking treatment for hearing voices. It is simply unacceptable that we have people dying in custody as a result of inadequate medical attention.

Then there are the cases of suicide, with 20 separate instances in the past decade. Many of these involved hanging incidents within cells and common areas. This is despite the royal commission making specific recommendations around the removal and visibility of hanging points in prisons.

Eighteen of these deaths occurred in road accidents when evading the police or as a direct result of police pursuits. In many of the 147 cases, relatives or friends of the deceased people spoke about their fear of being caught by the police. This year a 31-year-old man from New South Wales fell from a 13-storey balcony in his efforts to avoid being caught. Family members said he feared being bashed by the police if caught. This is Australia and this is the reality for our First Nations people.

I think TheGuardian has done a great job with its analysis, and I for one thank the newspaper for shining a light on this issue and doing the work that should have been done by state, territory and federal governments if they really, truly cared. If it weren't for the investigation by TheGuardian, these findings would have remained buried and the lives of these First Nations people would be just another case number in a failed system. We shouldn't have to rely on external research to tell us this issue still exists. This data demonstrates how successive governments have failed when it comes to providing the support required for our First Nations peoples and implementing the 339 recommendations of the royal commission.

We absolutely need justice targets in this countryâ€”state, territory and Commonwealth. The Commonwealth has continued to shirk its responsibility to show leadership on this issue. We need to be addressing incarceration rates. Why is it that in 2018 we still have disproportionate representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our justice system? Why is it that all states aren't on board yet with the custody notification system? In an area where the government has shown a bit of leadership in offering to help fund it, we still don't have it rolled out across the country to an adequate level. We know it helps to reduce deaths in custody. Why aren't we providing medical attention? For heaven's sake! Againâ€”it's 2018; why aren't we providing that attention? Is it something to do with the fact that states and territories can't access Medicare for prisoners? We need to be revisiting that issue as well. We need to be retraining and taking it seriously. When states like WA apologise for biased treatment from the police, follow it up with meaningful action!

We think that the federal government needs to show true leadership and call an urgent meeting between the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to finally address this issue. Otherwise people are going to be standing in this parliament in years to come, quoting more dreadful, awful statistics. This issue absolutely has to be addressed. We need to make sure that all the recommendations from the royal commission are implemented. We need to be doing more because there's more that needs to be done. This government needs to show leadership and drag the states and territories to the table, by hook or by crook, and require them to make change so that future generations don't end up in jail as another statistic.
Canberra Community

Senator SESELJA (Australian Capital Territoryâ€”Assistant Minister for Treasury and Finance) (13:13): We've got some wonderful faith based communities here in Canberra. I had the honour of attending one of them recently, and that was at the 15th anniversary of the C3 Church in Belconnen. I attended with Alistair Coe, Leader of the Opposition in the ACT Legislative Assembly and leader of the ACT Liberal Party. I want to take this opportunity to thank pastors Nick and Melissa Hind and the entire church community for hosting me at their wonderful facility. C3 Church Belconnen is active in the local community, running music programs for parents and young children and anxiety counselling services and courses, and supporting a number of local groups. I thank the church for this contribution. I've seen the work of C3 in Tuggeranong in particular, where they do an outstanding job, as do so many of our other faith based communities. But C3's work in the Belconnen community is really valuable, and it was a real pleasure to be able to celebrate this milestone with the church community. Nick and Melissa are a great family team, leading that church community, and I look forward to seeing their great work continue into the future, hopefully not just for another 15 years but well beyond.

I want to also pay tribute to a couple of our great local small-business owners in Tuggeranong. Clinton and Shubana Sheehan own and run the Erindale Cakery Bakery, and can I say it is absolutely delicious. They gave me a tour of their bakery and gave me and my staff perhaps too many goodies to take away. But they do some really delicious stuff. The Sheehans have owned Cakery Bakery since 2011 and make everything they sell fresh on-site. I think they employ about 30 staff. A lot of young people who get their first job at the bakery get trained up. It's great that this family-owned business is employing young people in the Tuggeranong Valley. They're down at the Erindale shops. It's also great to see them thriving after a fire in a neighbouring shop that forced them to shut their doors. I know a lot of people in the community missed the great treats they usually got from Cakery Bakery.

Small businesses like Cakery Bakery run by regular Australians like Clinton and Shubana need all of the support they can get. I'm very proud to be part of a government that is backing small business. We're doing that through instant asset write-offs, small-business tax cuts and red tape relief. We support our small business community in every way we can. I want to wish them all of the best, and I thank Clinton and Shubana for all of the work they do and for hosting me at the bakery recently.

Here in Canberra we have an amazing Indian communityâ€”an absolutely amazing, growing, thriving Indian communityâ€”and they've been making a great contribution to Canberra for many, many years. That's why I was absolutely delighted recently to have the opportunity to speak at the celebration of the 72nd Indian Independence Day. We had a celebration at Duffy Primary School last month. This fantastic event was hosted by the India-Australia Association of Canberra, which is a volunteer organisation based in Canberra providing community services here and in the surrounding region. It has been doing that for the last 39 years, and I was really honoured recently to be asked to become their patron. I want to particularly recognise Dharminder Sharma and Sandi Mitra for inviting me along to make a presentation and for hosting me.

Sandi is well known to many Canberrans. He is one of those people who is just so committed to his community. He is committed to his family. He works so hard. I see him in his workplace, but I also see him, when he has spare time, serving his local community with the India-Australia Association of Canberra. He is just everywhere. Sandi is one of those people who helps to make our community thrive. He's one of those people who really helps communities to integrate. When we've got amazing people like Sandi and an Indian community doing great things in Canberra, it is something that we can be very, very proud of.

I was also particularly honoured to present Mr Kanti Jinna with felicitations in celebration of his being awarded with an Order of Australia earlier this year. Kanti is also very well known in the local Indian community in Canberra. Beyond that, he is one of those tireless servants of the community. He's a fantastic fellowâ€”always smiling, always with a good story to tell. I want to formally congratulate Kanti on a well-deserved honour that was recognised at Duffy Primary School last month.

The valuable work of the IAAC goes far beyond hosting big events. It was founded in the seventies here in Canberra. The organisation aims to remove barriers and to facilitate relationships between the Indian and Australian cultural communities. Its volunteer team works tirelessly to create inclusive events, to promote understanding between a collection of cultures and to offer support to Indian migrants who are settling in the region or who require assistance with disability, aged-care and other community services. The organisation also provides various services in an effort to help Indians and all other Indo communities settle down in Canberra and make them feel at home away from home. I want to congratulate IAAC on the amazing work that it does serving our community and, particularly the Indian-Australian community here in the ACT.

We also have many, many talented science students here in Canberra and right across the ACT. I was honoured recently to be hosted by Simon Vaughan, who is the principal of Melrose High School, and shown how he and his team at Melrose are helping budding young scientists explore their passion for science through projects and investigations in their classes. Some of the projects the students are working on are at such a level they are under the supervision of some of our amazing researchers from the University of Canberra. I got to visit the science labs and hear from many students who could explain genetics to you far better than most adults certainly could. We even had one brave student demonstrate the science of direct currents and electrostatics with a Van de Graaff generator. I don't know if you've ever seen that. You hold onto it and your hair stands on end. It's quite a fun science experiment. The possibilities of where a passion for science can take you are wide open particularly for students here in Canberra with our great institutions like CSIRO, ADFA and our universities, which can lead to endless career opportunities.

I was further inspired by some of our young ACT students at the greenlight for girls event here in Canberra recently. I think it was also at Melrose High, from memory. There were more than 100 girls, from all over the ACT, gathered to hear from female leaders in STEM fields and learn about different careers in STEM. There has been much talk in this place, in recent times, about the vital importance of STEM careers and I hope all young students know that every opportunity is open to them, and they should pursue any subject they have a passion for.

The greenlight for girls event demonstrates the link between STEM and everything around us in a fun and interactive way. Participants were inspired by hands-on workshops led by role model professionals in STEM. Each girl was given the chance to experience four 45-minute workshops throughout the day. The girls enjoyed being led through various activities by naval engineers and cybersecurity experts and heard from computing experts. They had a great day celebrating the possibilities of STEM during National Science Week. The day was led by the Girl Guides, here in the ACT, who do an amazing job, and they received grant funding from the coalition government as part of the Inspiring Australiaâ€”Science Engagement Program to bring the event to fruition. Thank you to Michelle Cothe and her brilliant team for putting together an inspiring and engaging day for so many young girls. My daughter participated in it and I know she had a wonderful day. I look forward to hearing more about our future scientists, engineers and mathematicians and the life-changing work they are set to do in the future.

In the short time I have left I'd like to take this opportunity to congratulate the outstanding achievement of the ACT's very own Rohan Dhooria, on the occasion of winning the national title for under-21s in the Australian Table Tennis Championships. Well done! I'm told the final was one for the ages. After trailing 3-1 Rohan came back from the brink to claim the under-21 men's singles crown, taking the title 4-3 over Dominic Huang. Nineteen-year-old Rohan Dhooria is the only ACT player to hold two national titles, having won the under-15s in 2014 and now under-21s in 2018. Rohan has a goal to represent Australia at the coming Olympic Games in Tokyo as well as the Commonwealth Games. I wish him all the very best in his future endeavours. As someone who has only played table tennis in the rumpus room rather than competition I have the greatest respect for people who can play it at such a high level. There is certainly intense competition in our house, and I can only imagine what it's like in Rohan's house! Well done to Rohan and congratulations on an amazing achievement.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Meteorology, Wattle Day, Republican Movement

p.span: Bureau of Meteorology
Wattle Day
Republican Movement

Senator BILYK (Tasmania) (13:23): Firstly, today, I am speaking about one of the most essential services for all Australians: the Bureau of Meteorology Their observations and weather forecasts are relied on by people in all sorts of professionsâ€”farmers, transport workers, seafarers and aviators, just to name a few. It helps our emergency services to predict and manage natural disasters and to issue warnings and advisories to the public. The bureau's forecasts are watched closely by recreational fishers, bushwalkers and surfers. They also provide valuable data to our Antarctic researchers and climate scientists. The bureau's services are also relied on by Australians daily, when they're planning to go out, to determine what they might do or even what they might wear. It's incredible how much we rely on these services for our day-to-day decisions.

The Bureau of Meteorology is valued and trusted by all Australians. That's why I and my Tasmanian federal Labor colleagues have been extremely disturbed about recent reports that the bureau is moving local forecasting services interstate. Under the plan, forecasting services in most states, including Tasmania, will be moved to national forecasting teams in Melbourne and Brisbane. So much for decentralisation! The Community and Public Sector Union Tasmanian branch secretary, Madeline Northam, described it this way:
What the bureau is proposing is essentially creating two weather sausage factories, where staff in Melbourne or Brisbane will churn out weather forecasts for the whole country.

I know that other branches of the CPSU have also raised concerns about the loss of forecasting services in their states. One of the concerns that has been raised by the union is the risk to local communities during extreme weather events. This is particularly worrying when there is more than one major incident happening across Australiaâ€”the fear being, of course, that the larger population centre will get the most attention. The Tasmanian unions covering parks and forestry, firefighters and the State Emergency Service have described the decision as stupid and short-sighted. Gavin Cashion from the Police Association of Tasmania has raised concerns about how the loss of local forecasting could impact on Tasmania Police's search and rescue capability on both land and sea. Leigh Hills from the United Firefighters Union of Australia said that it's absolutely crucial to have local knowledge during fuel-reduction burns and high-fire-danger periods. CPSU Tasmania's general secretary, Tom Lynch, has warned that the bureau's decision will put lives at risk.

Concerns have also been raised by farming groups. Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia president, Tony Seabrook, said that the bureau could become a faceless organisation. He also said:
â€¦ farmers make day-to-day decisions based on the forecasting that we get, and they can be very significant decisions to do with livestock welfare.
â€¦ based on previous experience, the further away from the centre of activity that people like forecasters are, the less likely we'll get the accurate forecasting that we need.

They may say with computers they can do it just as well, but somehow or another most of us will have a grave fear that the centralisation of forecasting may actually mean forecasting â€¦ might not be as accurate.

My Tasmanian federal Labor colleagues and I are concerned about what this decision means for the quality of observations and forecasts in our state. Tasmania's federal Labor members and senators have written to the new Minister for the Environment, Ms Price, seeking an explanation as to why the change is actually necessary, and a guarantee that it will not adversely impact on forecasting in Tasmania. I understand that concerns have already been raised by Tasmanian Liberal senators, and I call on them to call on the minister for an urgent explanation.

While the Prime Minister has provided an assurance there will be no job losses at the bureau in Tasmania, this provides no comfort whatsoever to the Tasmanian community that the quality of local forecasting services will be maintained. In fact, it doesn't really give me any sense of assurance, either, because I want to know what the impact of the changes is on staff. We haven't been told yet, so we don't know. To be honest, the government's hollow assurances really don't reassure us all that much.

Many Tasmanians are concerned about maintaining the integrity of the bureau's excellent record when it comes to providing accurate and trusted observation and forecasts. We firmly believe that local forecasts are best undertaken by employees with local knowledge and local experience. Nonetheless, as I said, we look forward to the minister's explanation, which I urge the minister to provide as a matter of urgency.

On a different subject, Acting Deputy President Kitching, did you know there are over 1,000 species of wattle in Australia? They inhabit our landscape like no other plant. They are quintessentially Australian. Thoughts of wattle are intrinsically tied to thoughts of Australia. The two are intertwined and really difficult to separate. Since 1988, when the golden wattle was officially gazetted as Australia's national floral emblem, wattle has become as much a symbol of our national identity as the Australian flag or AdvanceAustraliaFair.

The first known use of wattle as an emblem in the Australian colonies was in fact in Hobart town in 1838, when a resident suggested wearing a sprig of wattle to celebrate the golden jubilee of European settlement of Australiaâ€”although on that occasion it was silver and black wattle, as golden wattle was yet to be introduced to Tasmania. Wattle Day was first held on 1 September 1910 in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Since 1992, national Wattle Day has been held on 1 September in all of Australia's states and territories. Before then, Australians in different states celebrated Wattle Day on different days between August and September.

From 1993, Wattle Day has held an additional meaning. The Australian Republic Movement has adopted this unique celebration as a day to campaign for an Australian head of state. In Tasmania, a Wattle Day barbecue was held at the appropriately named Republic Bar in Hobart. These barbecues were held nationally to allow Australians to start conversations about constitutional reforms to allow an Australian head of state. I was proud to celebrate Wattle Day and campaign for an Australian head of state with my Labor Senate colleagues Senator Brown and Senator Singh, along with Angela Wilson, Tasmanian Branch Convenor of the Australian Republic Movement. Ironically, the Republic Bar was previously named the Empire Hotel, showing how times have changed and how attitudes have changed.

While the 1999 referendum seems like a distant memory to many, the movement for Australia to stand on its own two feet as a proud, independent nation still has plenty of momentum. There are now almost four million more people on the electoral roll than there were then. This includes a whole new generation of Australians who couldn't vote at the time of the referendum 19 years ago. Of course, some of them weren't even born. So, it's time for this issue to be revisited. Labor has pledged to hold a national vote on an Australian head of state during the first term of a Shorten Labor government. The question we will put is simple: do you support an Australian Republic and an Australian head of state? This avoids the divisive debate we saw on the last referendum that clouded the issue by proposing a model that the Australian people were not in favour of.

We cannot repeat the mistakes of the 1999 referendum and give Australians one vote in order to settle two questions. If the yes campaign is successful, it will be followed by further debate and a vote about what the most appropriate model is, but the first hurdle is to get agreement for an Australian head of state in some form. We do not argue for a republic out of any disrespect for the Queen or her heirs, but the United Kingdom is a long way from Australia both geographically and, increasingly, culturally. There are no good reasons that the descendants of the winners of battles and invasions on an island on the other side of the world hundreds of years in the past should be the heads of state of our nation.

Australia is unique. Our land and our society are distinctive in the world. Our Indigenous culture is the world's oldest culture, and much of our plant and animal life is unique to this continent. Our landscape is unlike that anywhere else. We are a great success story as a society. One in four Australians were born overseas, and almost half have a parent who was born overseas. We have created a multicultural society that believes in fairness, tolerance and mateship. From across the seas, hundreds of different people have relocated under the Southern Cross in the hope of a better life. They have grown with our nation and, in turn, our nation has grown with them. It's time for our nation, like the old Empire Hotel in north Hobart, to change.
Pauline Hanson's One Nation

Senator BURSTON (New South Wales) (13:33): It may not be apparent to Australians, but the president of China, Xi Jinping, has something in common with a notorious Australian. I would invite members of the Senate to speculate on who that might be and what it might be that they have in common. We all know that the president of China is president for life. What Australian would seek to be president for life? I could not think of anything more abhorrent to our democracy, anything more un-Australian. The Anzacs went to war to protect and defend our democracy. It is the right of every Australianâ€”that is, provided that you are not a member of One Nation, because One Nation is the most un-Australian, undemocratic organisation in history.

Senator Hanson has declared herself president for life, just like the president of China. James Ashby told her to, because Jimmy controls her 24/7â€”the not-so-faceless man of One Nation. She is the only Australian, and One Nation the only political party in Australia, that follows the dictatorship model. There is no election for the leader or president of the party, no election for the national executive and no election for the state executive. What you see is what you get, forever, unless president for life decides otherwise. 'Jimmy told me so.' Wikipedia states:

President for life is a title assumed by or granted to some leaders to remove their term limit irrevocably as a way of removing future challenges to their authority and legitimacy. The title sometimes confers on the holder the right to nominate or appoint a successor.

Let's have a look at who she and Jimmy have hand-picked for the national executive. Who are they? Well, let me go through them one at a time. First is Pauline Hanson, president for life. 'Disagree with me and you're gone.' She once described herself as the 'mother of the nation' and more recently as 'senator for Australia'. Second is James Ashby, the proud holder of a criminal record and a diary thiefâ€”the man who brought down Peter Slipper. Jimmy is the man who shares a unit with the president for life here in Canberraâ€”a close relationship of no benefit to members of One Nation. He is a man who stalks my staff, both physically and by carrier service, as well as sending me vile text messages. The judge in the Ashbygate case described Jimmy as a 'psychopath'â€”how true. Third is Sean Black, a convicted rapist and wife basher. Fourth is Alex Jones. I don't really know him, but he would be a yes-man. Fifth is Michael Pucci, a prolific bully. He was considered for dismissal from employment for bullying but was instead promoted to the executive because president for life likes somebody with a bit of mongrel in them. That is why she hand-picked never-was-a-senator Roberts as the lead Queensland candidate for the Senate at the next federal election. She thinks he has a bit of mongrel in him. 'Jimmy told me so.' No other Australian political party has a president for lifeâ€”only One Nation. When I was a member of One Nation and representing them in the Senate, I asked her to 'please explain' but she couldn't or wouldn't. Just like she couldn't explain why she breaks deals, and handshake deals at that.
Senator Hanson interjectingâ€”

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Whish-Wilson ): Senator Burston, I remind you to direct your comments directly at the chair.

Senator BURSTON: Sorry, Acting Deputy President. But Jimmy knew. He had told her to. Just like she couldn't explain how the millions of dollars that One Nation has received from the taxpayer were spentâ€”the money that should have been spent to support the political objectives of those she represented. Why is money under the table and in the control of Senator Hanson being husbanded away? Is it for her old age or for more overseas trips? I must ask Jimmy. He will know. If only One Nation members had it so good.

One Nation is a family business. You have to pay $10,000 if you want to be endorsed as a candidate for the lower house and $25,000 if you want to be endorsed as lead candidate for the Senate. You also have to pay thousands of dollars to Jimmy Ashby's printing business. He has become quite wealthy since joining the One Nation gravy train. If the New South Wales Hanson-and-Jimmy-picked-and-controlled state executive want to fundraise, they need approval from Senator Hanson and Jimmy, and 40 per cent of the proceeds go to her. 'Jimmy told me so.' That's right. It's a family business.

The New South Wales executive have been told that they are under the total control of head officeâ€”in other words, the president for life and Jimmy. In an email to all New South Wales members, dated 9 March 2018, head office in part wrote in point form. First, information, ideas and policy flow from the ground up. Important decision-making flows the opposite way from the leadership of the national body. Second, the national executive are the total governing body of the party. The constitution lays out their ultimate powers as well as the factâ€”
Senator Hanson interjectingâ€”
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Burston, please take your seat. There is a point of order.
Senator Watt: It is very difficult to hear what Senator Burston is saying because of the constant interjections from Senator Hanson. I would just ask that she refrain so thatâ€”
Senator Hanson interjectingâ€”
Senator Watt: Now I can't hear myself think because of Senator Hanson interjecting. I just ask her to apply the same standards that she insists on from others.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I remind everyone in the chamber that a senator has a right to be heard in silence.

Senator BURSTON: Third, reimbursement costs for steering committee meetings must be pre-approved with receipts and paid invoices submitted with the claim. Fourth, states have no power to take control of membership information or to make representations to the media on behalf of the party unless pre-organised or pre-authorised with head office or the national executive. Fifth, HQ maintains control of the party's databases at all times. Sixth, directives of major decisions in each state will be maintained by the national bodyâ€”
Senator Hanson interjectingâ€”
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Hanson! Senator Watt, I think I know what your point of order is going to beâ€”
Senator Watt: Surely, we all want to hear what Senator Burston has got to say. Senator Hanson is very rudely continually interrupting and it makes it impossible to hear.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you for your point of order. Senator Hanson, you are in very close proximity to Senator Burston. While he's delivering his speech I'd ask that you listen to his speech in silence. You have plenty of opportunity to respond in the Senate.
Senator Hanson: I just don't like lies.

Senator BURSTON: I might point out to the Senate that this is a direct copy of an email sent to all members of New South Wales, which I'm happy to provide on the record to the Senate. Sixth, directives on major decisionsâ€”
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Burston, are you wanting to table it?

Senator BURSTON: No. I haven't got it with me, but I will table it in the future. Sixth, directives on major decisions in this state will be maintained by the national body. HQ's job is to approve any content sent to members. Seventh, no state executive is to hold funds for membership or applications as a middle man for the national body. That's right; it's a family business.

What has One Nation achieved since the last election? Zeroâ€”increased immigration and rural towns continue to die. They lost half their senators. They lost the balance of power in the Senate. I can go on and on.

Since it started contesting elections in 1996, the president for life, Jimmy and others have forced out 23 of 30 elected members of parliament, a strike rate of 77 per cent. Of those 30 elected members, six currently represent One Nation: two senators, three in the WA Legislative Council and one in the Queensland Legislative Assembly. Two were disqualified from sitting in the Senate, Heather Hill and Malcolm Roberts. Rod Culleton resigned from the party before being disqualified from the Senate. Nineteen resigned in their first term. Two lasted a full term with the party before being defeated at the next election: Bill Flynn and Len Harris. Only one elected member has been re-elected for the party: Rosa Lee Long won Tablelands at the 2001 Queensland State election and was re-elected in 2004 and 2006, but as an Independent. No wonder One Nation has collapsed in the polls.
People ask me why I left One Nation. I honour my word and handshake deals. I love my country and will not be a member of a party that is a dictatorship. Would you?

We need positive action taken now to make this country great, to grow our economy. We need leaders with a strong track record that can deliver to the Australian people and that's why I'm proud to lead the United Australia Party in the Senate.
There are many stories about One Nation. This has only been one of them.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: A point of order, Senator Smith?
Senator Dean Smith: I propose that Senator Burston be given an extension of time.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: That's not a point of order, Senator Smith.

talker.name: Whish-Wilson, Sen Peter (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Water

Senator IAN MACDONALD (Queensland) (13:43): Today I want to speak about opportunities for water storage, water reticulation and water management, particularly in the northern part of our country, which receives more rainfall than any other part of Australia and, indeed, more rainfall than many parts of the world. Regrettably, there are all too few dams in the north. The last that I can recall being built in the north, and really anywhere in Australia, was the Fairbairn Dam at Emerald, which was built by a Liberal government back some decades ago. Then there's the Burdekin Dam near where I live, again initiated by the Fraser Liberal government some years ago. The Tinaroo Dam in the far north was a little time before that. But, since then, there has been very little activity on water storage and reticulation anywhere in my state of Queensland and not much across the Top End, apart from, of course, the outstanding example of the Ord River dam. Again that was an initiative of the Menzies government more than 50 years ago.

The coalition government federally, following its north Australia white paper initiatives, in developing northern Australia has been trying to get the Queensland state government interested in some water storage proposals in the north of the state. The drought that is gripping parts of south-west Queensland and western New South Wales these days shows the absolute necessity, urgency and critical nature of getting managed water facilities in our country where we have access to this huge rainfall.

The CSIRO have just completed major inquiries into three water storage proposals across the north of Australiaâ€”one at the Mitchell River, one around Darwin and one at the Fitzroy River in Western Australia. CSIRO, never known for the lightness of their workâ€”they always do everything in a very detailed fashionâ€”have spent some years, at federal government expense, I might say, investigating these three proposals. Just a couple of weeks ago they put out the results of their investigation and they are all very, very positive. I look forward to the Queensland government, who, of course, own the streams and riversâ€”they're the only ones that can do anythingâ€”reading these reports from CSIRO and doing something positive to harness, store, use and manage the water that is available in northern Australia.

Apart from these three sites across the north, there is a lot of other interest in water facilities. Pursuant to the coalition government's northern Australia white paper and the money that was allocated following it to water investigation proposals, the coalition government has instituted feasibility studies in relation to the Nullinga Dam west of Cairns, the Urannah Dam west of Bowen and just south of Ayr, where I live, the Cave Hill dam out near Cloncurry and the Mount Isa area and also the Big Rocks Weir on the Burdekin River near Charters Towers, which is part of the Hells Gates proposal north-west of Townsville. These feasibility studies have been funded by the Commonwealth government, with not a cent put into them by the Queensland government, I might say. The Hells Gates feasibility study, I understand, was made available to the Queensland government some months ago now, but it still hasn't been released publicly by the Queensland government. Why, you might ask, do the Queensland government have anything to do with it? They haven't put one cent into the Hells Gates proposal but regrettably, under our Constitution, as I said before, if it happens within streams, rivers or any water within the state then it is the constitutional responsibility of the Queensland government. So, regrettably, all of these proposals have to go to the Queensland government, who sit on them, no doubt working out how they can take some political advantage of initiatives that the Commonwealth have introduced.

I wanted to also mention the Tully-Millstream proposals that were around quite a lot almost 30 years ago before they were shelved by a Labor government at the time. The Tully Falls comes off the Atherton Tablelands near Tully, just south of Cairns, and the water goes through the Koombooloomba Dam and then falls dramatically to the Kareeya power station, with a very small turbine at the end of it that's been operating for decades already. There were proposals to increase the activity in that Tully Hydro scheme and this would have given northern Australia and Northern Queensland, in particular, guaranteed baseload power from a renewable sourceâ€”waterâ€”with no carbon emissions whatsoever.

Of course the Labor Party, because they are controlled by the Greens and exist in government in Queensland only because of Greens preferences, refuse to do anything about it. But there have been a number of proposals. The old Tully Millstream proposal has been updated, and a proposal was put forward by the then member for Hinchinbrook, Mr Andrew Cripps, who was a very effective member for Hinchinbrook in North Queensland and an excellent minister for natural resourcesâ€”probably the best Queensland's had in 20 or 30 years. He put forward a very detailed proposal for upgrading that old in-river hydro scheme. There is another proposal around, instituted by a number of dedicated North Queenslanders and a group called the Queensland Electricity Users Network, of which Ms Jennifer Brownie is the coordinator. They've looked at the old Tully Millstream proposal and have made calculations and done a lot of engineering work at their own expense on how the Tully Millstream could be converted into a pumped hydro scheme. It would involve a small location, a small collection pit, in the Tully River, at the bottom of the falls, where the water could be captured and then pumped up the hillâ€”again, at night-time, when there isn't such a big demand for electricityâ€”into Koombooloomba Dam and then released back down during the day, between 4 pm and 6 pm, when electricity use in the north is at astronomical levels.

Unfortunately in the north now we have to rely on transmission lines from way down south. We're subject to monopoly control by a Queensland government-owned business entity that makes a squillion dollars out of users in the north, particularly business users, who are not subsidised. This Queensland government business entity makes a squillion dollars at the expense of people in the north, particularly businesses, and the Queensland government pockets the money, because they can't manage money; they're broke and they use the taxpayers, the electricity users, to address this. But this idea of a pumped hydro ticks all the boxes. It provides baseload power. It provides power that is renewable. It provides power that has no carbon emissions, if you're worried about those. It is cost-effective. And we are hoping that the federal governmentâ€”because the Queensland government won't do itâ€”might do a concept study into pumped hydro at Tully Millstream and, if that looks good, do a full feasibility study in the hope that when all this expert evidence comes out the Queensland government might at last ignore the Greens, who control them, and actually do something for water storage and for more-reliable electricity, particularly in the north of our state.
Energy

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland) (13:53): Last week I attended Incitec Pivot in Brisbane, which is a local manufacturing plant that employs about 200 local workers. I was there that day with the Leader of the Opposition, federal Labor leader Bill Shorten; our shadow minister Jason Clare; and our fantastic Labor candidate for Bonner, Jo Briskey. Incitec Pivot employs about 200 locals at that plant in Brisbane. They have plenty of other plants around Queensland and operations that employ almost 1,000 workers across the state. They're a very important part of our local economy. But it's been well publicised for a period of time that they have been really struggling with the high price of domestic gas in Australia, so much so that it is creating a lot of uncertainty for their workforce and for their future operations as well.

That's why it was pleasing when we were there that day to be part of the announcement that federal Labor leader Bill Shorten made, the heart of which was basically ensuring that Australian energy needs are put first. This was really important for local manufacturing and was specifically why we made the announcement at Incitec Pivot in Brisbane. Effectively, the announcement we made is aimed at boosting local gas supply and putting downward pressure on prices, and all this is designed to protect Australian jobs at the same time, particularly those in manufacturing. As I mentioned, there were 200 workers there at Incitec Pivot, but we know that there are thousands and thousands of manufacturing jobs across Australia that depend on affordable and reliable gas.

Labor's permanent gas export control trigger can be used when prices are too high, not just when there's a shortfall. There is a real contrast between the policy that Labor have put forward and what the piecemeal approach from those opposite has been in terms of their interest in gas. Labor will also boost supply for domestic use by introducing a national interest test for new LNG export facilities, and we will also give the ACCC new powers to monitor prices and crack down on anticompetitive behaviour. These are really important steps. Unlike those opposite, these steps tackle reliability but also tackle the price, which they haven't gone near. We also know that the resources minister admits that high gas prices are putting pressure on local manufacturing jobs, and this is a direct quote from him: 'I accept that prices of $10 are a great threat to jobs and manufacturing; prices of $8 are also a threat to jobs and manufacturing.' It was the resources minister himself, Matt Canavan, who said that. Unlike those opposite, who've talked about this, Labor has been prepared to take action, and we announced that at Incitec Pivot in Brisbane. Labor's plan will put downward pressure on gas prices. This will be a great result for Aussie manufacturers, for power generators and also, from a Labor point of view, for jobs and families.

I'd like to acknowledge the leadership on this policy issue of the Australian Workers' Union, particularly their national secretary, Dan Walton, and their Queensland secretary, Steve Baker, as well. Not only have they been advocating for their members, they've also been advocating for the broader community on this issue as well because they understand how important this is for Australian workers and for Australian families.

It's important to note that Labor can only make announcements like this because we are stable, we are united and we have a leadership team who are listening to Australian families and Australian businesses and are prepared to announce policies that will work for those people. There's a clear contrast between what Labor have been presenting to the Australian people and what those opposite have been presenting. Let's look at this, because this mob have been in government for five years. They've been in government for five years, and what is their record on energy and electricity? We know they've had chaos and dysfunction and they've been able to come up with a coherent policy that they can unite their backbench on. We know their record after five years in government is that prices are up, pollution is up, reliability is down and policy uncertainty is playing havoc with the community. It's playing havoc with Australian families. It's playing havoc with Australian businesses, and it also is leading to a lack of new generation, and families are paying the price.

We know that, for almost a year, the previous Prime Minister and the previous energy minister worked on a policy called the National Energy Guarantee. They claimed that that policy was going to provide certainty. They claimed that that policy was going to reduce prices by $150 a year. Yet all they did was use that policy to undermine the former Prime Minister and knife him in the back. And what have they got since? They've actually got no policy. They've completely abandoned the National Energy Guarantee as a result. Do you know what their own modelling said? It said that, if we have no policy, it will lead to price increases of $300 over a decade. That is actually what we're seeing from the government. They've abandoned their policy. They've abandoned the National Energy Guarantee, which basically means that, with no policy, prices are going to go up by $300.

We know that they used this. The Turnbull hatersâ€”the Dutton supportersâ€”didn't care about Australian families. When they undermined the National Energy Guarantee, they just wanted to undermine the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull. They didn't care about Australian families. They didn't care about the high cost that families are paying under this government. They were prepared to use that policy that they'd been working on for almost 12 months to undermine the Prime Minister and get rid of him. But let's look at the contrasting fortunes of the two architects of that policy. We know what they did when they knifed the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull, in the back. We know that part of it. But the second architect of that policy is the former minister Josh Frydenberg. And what did they do with him? They actually promoted him. Can you believe this? They worked on this policy for almost 12 months, and then they used it to knife one and promote the other. Energy policy under this government is an absolute farce!
The PRESIDENT: The time for senators' statements has expired.
MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (14:00): I advise the Senate that Senator Birmingham will be absent from question time today and tomorrow due to overseas ministerial business. In Senator Birmingham's absence, Senator Payne will represent the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment; Senator McKenzie will represent the Minister for Education; and Senator Canavan will represent the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Energy.
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Prime Minister

Senator POLLEY (Tasmania) (14:00): My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Cormann. In an article in this morning's HeraldSun, on Prime Minister Scott Morrison's 'expletive-laden tirade' over GST, it is revealed that former Prime Minister Turnbull was forced to sideline then Treasurer Morrison in critical GST negotiations after he abused his Tasmanian counterpart in an 'expletive-laden tirade'.
Government senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order on my right!
Senator POLLEY: Can Prime Minister Morrison guarantee he did not call Liberal Tasmanian Treasurer Peter Gutwein an 'effing mendicant'?
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Before I call Senator Cormann, I will insist again on silence during the question being askedâ€”
Senator Cameron interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: particularly during my rulings, as well.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (14:01): I thank Senator Polley for that question. As I have tried to explain to the opposition once before: don't believe everything you read in the newspaper. This never happened. The Prime Minister has made very clear it never happened, and Mr Gutwein, the great Treasurer for the great state of Tasmania, has made clear it never happened. I am happy to quote from his statement:
â€¦ I can confirm that during our discussions relating to the GST the phrase attributed in today's media to Mr Morrison was not used.

Let me just talk, though, about the reforms to the GST sharing arrangements that Mr Morrison, as Treasurer, put together. He was, of course, the architect of a reform that was in the too-hard basket for too long. Indeed, Mr Morrison has been able to deliver a better, fairer deal on the GST to Western Australia, in a way that is fair to every other state, including Tasmaniaâ€”indeed, in a way that leaves Tasmania $112 million better off.

We've got Mr Shorten gallivanting around Western Australia, talking with forked tongue, essentially trying to make people in Western Australia believe that he is on a unity ticket with the Liberal Party and the National Party when it comes to GST sharing arrangements. He actually used the words, 'We're on a unity ticket.'

I see Senator Polley shaking her head. Well, I suggest to you that you take it up with your leader, because those are precisely the words that he used when he was in Western Australia. If you are saying to me that that's not true, I suggest you take that up with Mr Shortenâ€”unless you are now representing the Labor Party policy on the GST. Are you saying that the Labor Party is not on a unity ticket with the Liberal-National party on GST sharing arrangements? Now she's not telling me anything anymore.
The truth is that Mr Shorten has gone into WA; he's said, 'We're on a unity ticket.' He says he wants to legislateâ€” (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Polley, a supplementary question.
Senator POLLEY (Tasmania) (14:03): In the article, which refers to the revelations as:
â€¦ the third damaging leak â€¦ to rock the Morrison Government â€¦
it's revealed that a deal with the Tasmanian government was only clinched after Mr Turnbull negotiatedâ€”
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, on a point of order?
Senator Wong: I'm not sure the microphone's on.
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
Senator Wong: Well, I can barely hear Senator Polley.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, I thank you for repeating my admonition that I hear silence during questions. I have asked for it repeatedly, yesterday and today. Senator Polley, I could hear.
Senator Cormann: She can start again.
The PRESIDENT: All right. Senator Cormann has asked you to start again because he couldn't hear the question. I will double-check that the microphone has been switched on.
Senator POLLEY: In the article, which refers to the revelations as:
â€¦ the third damaging leak â€¦ to rock the Morrison Government â€¦

it's revealed that a deal with the Tasmanian government was only clinched after Mr Turnbull negotiated directly with the Tasmanian Premier, Will Hodgman. On how many occasions has Prime Minister Morrison been sidelined from negotiations as a result of his inability to deal respectfully with his counterparts?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (14:04): Firstly, I reject the premise of the question and refer Senator Polley to my answer of her main question.

The second thing I would say is that Mr Morrisonâ€”now the Prime Minister, then the Treasurerâ€”is the architect of historic reforms to our GST-sharing arrangements, which will deliver a fairer, better deal for Western Australia in a way that is fair to every other state, including and in particular, Tasmania. Of course, then Prime Minister Turnbull, then Treasurer Morrison and I, as the core of the economic team, worked as a close partnership as we implemented this particular reform proposal and engaged with state and territory governments around Australia.

I was responsible for dealing with the state government in Western Australia. Mr Morrison and the Prime Minister at the time shared responsibility in relation to some of the interaction with states on the eastern seaboard.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Polley, a final supplementary question.

Senator POLLEY (Tasmania) (14:05): Given former Prime Minister Turnbull had to bail out his second-rate Treasurer, is it any wonder this illegitimate Prime Minister was his colleagues' third choice as leader?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (14:06): This is now getting quite desperate. As I've said now a couple of times, Mr Morrison is the architect of a reform that has been in the too-hard basket for years and years and years. Indeed, the WA's share of the GST started to head to below 30c in the dollar under the period of the Rudd and Gillard governments. Prime Minister Gillard initiated the Brumby-Greiner review and then ignored the recommendations on how the system should be reformed.

It is our government that initiated top-up payments to Western Australia, to stop the drop in WA's share of the GST, as a short-term measure. It is our government that commissioned the Productivity Commission review. It is our government that has put on the table a genuine long-term solution. We are still waiting for Bill Shorten to clarify his position, because Senator Polley seems to think he doesn't support a fairer deal for WA.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The PRESIDENT (14:07): Before I proceed to the next question, I draw to the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of the Australian Political Exchange Council's 22nd delegation from Vietnam. On behalf of all senators, I wish you a warm welcome to Australia and, in particular, to the Senate.

Honourable
senators: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Aged Care

Senator McGRATH (Queensland) (14:07): My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care, Senator Scullion. Can the minister advise what the coalition government is doing to ensure the highest possible care standards for our senior Australians?

Senator SCULLION (Northern Territoryâ€”Minister for Indigenous Affairs and Leader of The Nationals in the Senate) (14:07): I thank the senator for the question. Under the coalition government, our investment in residential care places has increased each and every single year. Since our election in 2013 aged-care spending has increased by more than an additional billion dollars of extra support each and every year. That means our total Commonwealth investment in aged care is a record $18.6 billionâ€”
Senator Polley interjectingâ€”

Senator SCULLION: or almost $4.5 billion more than Labor provided in its last budget, Senator Polley. As we continue to fix this fiscal mess left by those opposite we can continue to make new investments. Just today the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aged Care announced an additional $106 million to support better facilities, better care and better standards for aged care. This includes an additional $16 million investment for the new national Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission, which will be a one-stop shop to police the quality of services and to ensure better care and better standards in aged care. As the Prime Minister announced today, this will bolster the Commonwealth's ability to respond to wrongdoing and any risk to the provision of services to our senior Australians.

We are also announcing $90 million to support aged-care providers, with $40 million supporting regional, rural and remote seniors in Australia who were so badly forgotten by those opposite when they were in government. That will be supported by this new investment and it's something that my colleagues and I in the National Party are very proud to have delivered. This will improve, maintain and expand infrastructure, ensuring older Australians in these locations receive the very same level of support that people receive in the cities.

We are also making a $50 million investment to support residential aged-care providers and their staff to improve the quality and standards of care across the sector. Because this is such a priority for our government, funding will begin flowing from next week.
The PRESIDENT: Senator McGrath, a supplementary question?
Senator McGRATH (Queensland) (14:09): Can the minister advise how these measures build on the government's reforms to the aged-care sector?

Senator SCULLION (Northern Territoryâ€”Minister for Indigenous Affairs and Leader of The Nationals in the Senate) (14:10): I thank the senator for that question. The investment today builds on the record investment this government has madeâ€”$18.6 billion.
Senator Polley: You've gutted it over the last four years!

Senator SCULLION: We would know, again, from those who continue to interject on the other side, that it was $4.5 billion in their last budget. There has been no greater friend of senior Australians than the coalition government. We are delivering an additional 14,000 high-level home care packages over four years, which is on top of the 6,000 high-level packages already released last year. By 2021-22, more than 74,000 high-level home care packages will be available, which is an increase of 86 per cent since last year. At the same time, residential aged-care places continue to grow: $12.7 billion last year to more than $14.9 billion in 2012. That represents an average growth of 5.3 per cent per year. We are going to allocate more than 14,000 places. That is a record. (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator McGrath, a final supplementary question?
Senator McGRATH (Queensland) (14:11): Why is it so important that senior Australians and their loved ones have confidence in the quality of Australia's aged-care sector?

Senator SCULLION (Northern Territoryâ€”Minister for Indigenous Affairs and Leader of The Nationals in the Senate) (14:11): All Australian seniors deserve our protection, support, care, respect and love. It is the least we can do as a nation for our elders. They are those who have built up us into the nation that we are today. The measures announced today are all about protecting seniors and making them safer. This is the first upgrade of aged-care standards in more than 20 years. Not only are we strengthening the standards but, importantly, we are supporting aged-care facilities to meet the new standards. This means 2,700 aged-care homes and 366,000 staff will get the training and support that they need to transition to the strengthened aged-care quality standards. This is part of the National-Liberal government's commitment ensuring the 1.3 million older Australians receiving aged care have support and confidence in the safety and quality of their care. This is how we care for, protect, respect and love our seniors.
Drought

Senator KETTER (Queenslandâ€”Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (14:12): My question is to the minister representing the Deputy Prime Minister, Senator McKenzie. A video produced, authorised and distributed on social media by Prime Minister Morrison claims that reports about the drought are sensationalised and that there is too much emotion being pushed. Does the minister agree with the video's assertion that farmers struggling to feed their cattle have 'gotto pay what they have got to pay'.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (14:12): I haven't seen said video. But having toured drought-affected communities a lot over the last couple of months, there is a wide range of views on the ground in those communitiesâ€”whether it is in your home state of Queensland, which is 57 per cent drought declared, or New South Wales, which is 100 per cent drought declaredâ€”about how the farmers are being perceived. We know Australians right across this country have been incredibly generous, particularly those in the east coast capital cities, with financial support for our drought-affected farmers. Australians are donating at record levels to the Red Cross, to the CWA and to the National Farmers' Federation to ensure that those communities actually have the financial support that they need as they are going through this very, very difficult time.

If I am correctly interpreting your inference about what the people on the video are saying, some farmers who I speak to want to make sure that it is very clear that they are portrayed as strong, resilient small businessmen and women who are doing it tough and who are managing what is a situation of drought in this country. If you are a farmerâ€”say, up Quilpie wayâ€”you may have exceptionally dry years every three out of 10 years. If you are down in Victoria, that ratio is obviously a lot less. Whilst this outpouring of support is there and they appreciate it, they also want to remind the Australian public that they are resilient small businessmen and women.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Ketter, a supplementary question.

Senator KETTER (Queenslandâ€”Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (14:14): Prime Minister Morrison's video approvingly quotes a feedlot operator as saying, 'In a way a drought is a necessary evil, because it will cut out that bottom 10 per cent that probably shouldn't be there anyway.' Is it the Liberal-National government's position that 10 per cent of Australia's farmers should quit the industry?

Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (14:15): No. Obviously, the Australian government, including Prime Minister Morrison, are doing all we can to support our farmers and the affected communities through our over $1.8 billion investment in a range of measuresâ€”from changing asset tests through making sure farm household allowance is a lot more easy to apply for and to ensuring we've got rural financial counsellors on the ground because some farmers will be having to make very serious and difficult decisions about how they structure their business going forward. Is this something they want to continue to do?

These are very serious questions that farmers are facing all the time, especially in these positions around drought, because it is at the extreme end of profitability. When I saw the Tully family up in Quilpie, they had been in drought for six years. They said to me, 'Anyone who is still left in our community will be okay, because we have been able to structure our businesses in the way to get us through.'
The PRESIDENT: Senator Ketter, a final supplementary question.

Senator KETTER (Queenslandâ€”Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate) (14:16): Prime Minister Morrison's video dismisses concerns on the basis that drought has been part of the Australian agriculture scene for many years'. Why is it that at the same time the Australian people are making an extraordinary effort to assist our farmers during drought Prime Minister Morrison is promoting material that dismisses those who are hurting the most?

Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (14:16): Again, I haven't seen the video, but I know firsthand that the drought is the No. 1 priority of the Prime Minister, and he's been very clear about that. He hasn't just backed it up with a quick tourâ€”what is it that Bill's dropped? $20 million worth of supportâ€”but with real, tangible and practical measures to help our communities and our farmers. I am happy to take any Labor Party senator in this place with me into a drought affected community and to talk about the range of views on the ground, about how they are structuring their business and how the drought is affecting them. That was the feedlot owner being quoted. Those are his words. That is a real perspective of someone who is going through the drought.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, a point of order.
Senator Wong: I thought the minister's answer was that she hadn't seen the video and now she's saying she is quoting it. A point of order on direct relevance: has she seen the video or not?
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, that is another question, not so much a point of order on direct relevance.
Senator McKENZIE: I had completed my answer, but to clarify for Senator Wong I have not seen the videoâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator McKenzie! I provided additional time for the answer given there were interruptions thenâ€”
Senator McKenzie: He talked about a feedlot owner so I was referring to that.
Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement

Senator HANSON-YOUNG (South Australia) (14:18): My question is to the Minister representing the trade minister, Senator Payne. The TTP-11 allows global corporations to sue governments who make laws in the interests of their citizens and the environment under insidious ISDS clauses. It weakens protection of labour rights. It removes labour market testing and does not even mention climate change. This is a dud deal for Australia. It is a deal for corporations, not Australian workers or consumers. When will the government stop spinning and tell the Australian people the truth? This is a deal for their mates in big business and not a deal for the peopleâ€”
The PRESIDENT: A point of order, Senator Macdonald?

Senator Ian Macdonald: My point of order relates to questions. The standing orders clearly say that facts can be used if they are relevant to the question, but they do not allow arguments. This comment in the question that this is a 'dud deal' is purely commentary. It's an argument. It's this senator's opinion and it should not be allowed as a question. If she wants to debate it there is time for that later, but these are not questions and shouldn't be allowed, I suggest with respect.

The PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Macdonald. On this issue, I said I would come back to the chamber after I gave senators a chance to make submissions to me yesterday. I have received at least one. I'll be coming back to the chamber tomorrow. I urge all senators to read standing order 73, in the application of which there has been substantial slippage, which says that questions shall not contain arguments, inferences, imputations or epithets. Statements of facts can be used where they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible. There is a habit of questions including more than is strictly necessary, and I will, in our next sitting session after I come back to the chamber, start to more strictly apply this provision. Senator Hanson-Young.
Senator HANSON-YOUNG: I had finished my question.
The PRESIDENT: Okay. I'll call Senator Payne.

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:20): Thank you very much, Mr President. I was actually waiting for Senator Hanson-Young's question, as opposed to her narrative. Nevertheless, it gives me a valuable opportunity to speak to the chamber in relation to the TPP-11, which is one of the most comprehensive trade deals ever concluded. In fact, it will eliminate 98 per cent of tariffs for 11 countries with a combined GDP of more than A$13.8 trillion and close to 500 million consumers. The big winners from this FTA are going to be Australian farmers, manufacturers, service providers, small businesses and all exporters because it's going to be easier for them to sell their goods and supply services in a free trade area that spans half the globe.

In 2017, almost one-quarter of Australia's total exports, which were worth $92 billion, went to the countries that are part of the TPP-11, and that is going to continue to grow as tariffs fall under the TPP-11. As Senator Birmingham referred to yesterday, modelling has been undertaken internationally by Brandeis International Business School and Johns Hopkins University that shows that Australia is forecast to see $15.6 billion in net annual benefits to national income by 2030. What the TPP-11 provides is improved access to markets where Australia already has FTAs, such as Japanâ€”for example, building on our existing bilateral FTA, including accelerated reductions on Japan's tariffs on beef and elimination of a range of Japan's cheese tariffs. It's also going to create Australia's first FTA with Canada and Mexico, giving Australian exporters preferential access to two of the world's top 20 economies for the first time. I would have thought that those in this chamber who support business, support small business, support manufacturers, support jobs, support farmers, support service providers and support exporters would recognise the value of this initiative andâ€” (Timeexpired)

Senator HANSON-YOUNG (South Australia) (14:22): I have a supplementary question on the topic of caring for and supporting Australian workers. The TPP-11 commits Australia to accepting unlimited numbers of temporary workers from Canada, Mexico, Chile, Japan, Malaysia and Vietnam by exempting these nations from labour market testing. Why is the government not backing Australian workers? Tell us and tell us truthfully.

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:23): I think it is important to note that the TPP-11 doesn't change the skills and experience requirements that need to be met by foreign workers who are applying for a temporary skilled visa to work in Australia. That means that workers from the TPP-11 signatory countries remain subject to and must satisfy any skills assessment required for the visa process. Workers from the signatory countries also remain subject to and must satisfy licensing and registration processes which are required by state and territory governments.

As free trade agreements have developed over time, including when those opposite were in government and since we have been in government, there have been a range of approaches to labour market testing.
