But one of the things I would note is that all of Australia's trade agreements with provisions on the temporary movement of professionals have also included waivers on labour market testing, including, as I said, those from both sides of the chamber. We are not concerned about the sorts of issues that Senator Hanson-Young has raised, because the evidence shows, to the contraryâ€” (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Hanson-Young, a final supplementary question?

Senator HANSON-YOUNG (South Australia) (14:24): The Labor Party has said today that they're going to back the TPP and vote with the government in the hope of changing the arrangements in government. Can the minister clarify if the TPP can simply be renegotiated, or is this a pipedream and an empty promise from the Labor Party?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:24): I presume Senator Hanson-Young is yelling at the chamber because that is her favoured method of communication, but it doesn't help make her point any less false. In fact, we have welcomed the constructive approach by those opposite on matters of foreign affairs and matters of international trade, in engaging in a sensible discourse and a sensible discussion. In fact, the previous minister acknowledged that in his second reading speech in the House in August this year, in terms of his work with the shadow minister for trade.

Of course, any amendment to the TPP-11 would be subject to consensus by all parties. That is part of its process. But what I do think is important is that there are people in the chamber who are interested in jobs, there are people in the chamber who are interested in the growth of Australian industry and there are people in the chamber who are interested in small businesses. Unfortunately, that doesn't include anyone sitting down there.
Energy

Senator MARTIN (Tasmania) (14:25): My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Energy, Senator Canavan. Can the minister please update the Senate on how the coalition government is focused on driving power prices down and how our resource sectors can contribute?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:25): I thank Senator Martin for his very relevant and timely question. The government has a laser-like focus to reduce power prices. The No. 1 focus of the Minister for Energy is to reduce prices. Some successes have been made in the past year. Electricity prices in the wholesale market are down by 25 per cent. Gas spot prices are also down by around 20 to 25 per cent in the past year and a half. We have seen that flow through to the retail level in some contracts in different states across Australia.

Those reductions have come about from actions the government has taken. We have removed the ability of electricity companies to review regulatory decisions through the limited merits review process. That has helped save consumers $6Â½ billion on their electricity bills. We have, for the first time, introduced a control framework for gas exports to make sure that there is first sufficient gas for Australians before it is exported overseas. That has clearly helped relieve pressure in gas markets and contributed to that reduction in prices by around a quarter. This morning I met with gas producers to recommit to the heads of agreement we signed last year to ensure that uncontracted gas is first offered to Australian businesses to protect Australian jobs. That is a key focus of this governmentâ€”to support Australian jobs in our manufacturing sector.

There is more to do in response to the ACCC report that we commissioned last year. We are committing to introducing a safety net on prices for consumers. We are committing to ensuring that we have stronger competition laws, including the ability to break up electricity companies that continue to act in an anticompetitive way. And of course we support the investment in reliable full-time power, including coal and gas power. We don't shy away from using all our resources to bring people's power bills down.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Martin, a supplementary question.
Senator MARTIN (Tasmania) (14:28): Can the minister explain or advise of what more can be done to ensure a long-term solution to gas supply and prices?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:28): As I was outlining, we have taken significant action in the past year and a half to ensure that Australian gas can be used for Australian jobs first and foremost, and we remain committed to that. But in the long term we need to make sure that we continue to develop the gas supplies of our nation.
Senator Kim Carr interjectingâ€”

Senator CANAVAN: I want to support and make sure, as I know Senator Carr over there wants to ensure, that we have a strong manufacturing sector in Victoria. But his party in Victoria are not supporting the development of the gas resources that could help underpin our production. Respected energy and resource columnist Matt Stevens, in theFinancialReview, I think summed it up very well the other day. He said:

So the withering of Victoria's offshore gas estate means and the state's refusal to allow onshore drilling of any kind means Victoria will rely ever more on gas that travels a long way, by either real or virtual pipeline. And suddenly a 50-year energy advantage will disappear.
Well, I don't want to see that happen, and to make sure it doesn't happen we need to use and develop our gas resources. (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Martin, a final supplementary question.
Senator MARTIN (Tasmania) (14:29): Can the minister advise what would be the consequences of the government not taking action to reduce power prices?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:29): There are thousands of jobs on the line here for our country. Over the last year, around 15 per cent of the jobs created in Australia were in the manufacturing sectorâ€”nearly 50,000 jobs. We're very proud of the fact that we have supported a strong employment market that is also helping to support a strong manufacturing sector. If we cannot turn around this energy situation, if we do not develop our resources and if we do not back the use of coal-fired power, gas-fired power and renewable powerâ€”all types of powerâ€”we will put those thousands of jobs at risk. We will put our heritage and tradition as a strong manufacturing nation at risk. We cannot conduct heavy manufacturing in this nation unless we use the fossil fuels of this nation to do that. Those on the other side are turning their backs on the workers in our coal-fired power stations and our gas-fired power stations. You'll never hear a word from them in defence of the hard work, effort and contribution that our electricity workers make in gas- and coal-fired power stations. We support them; they don't.
Nuclear Waste

Senator PATRICK (South Australia) (14:30): My question is to the Minister for Resources and Northern Australia, Senator Canavan. On 28 August, in the wake of the leadership spill, I passed by a television and saw you talking on SkyNews. During that interview, you talked about the sad state of governmentâ€”
Government senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Stop, Senator Patrick. On my right! I have asked for silence during questions. Senator Patrick, please recommence after 'SkyNews'.

Senator PATRICK: During that interview, you talked about the sad state of government, saying: 'We've got to be up-front with the Australian people. We need to be up-front in what we're trying to achieve and be open with them about the risks and issues and challenges we face.' Minister, in the spirit of being up-front, can you advise how the outcome of the radioactive waste management vote at Kimba and Hawker will be factored into your decision on that proposed facility? Specifically, are you standing by the 65 per cent figure that you told this chamber last year was the test for broad community support for this project?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:31): I will come to your question, Senator Patrick, but I will start by saying that I'm happy to repeat what I've also said at community forums that I attended in Kimba and Hawker over the last month around how we will now proceed with the consultation on the radioactive waste facility. In particular, the ballot we hope to conduct soon will be one factor we take into account in our decision-making but not the only factor, and that has always been my position and the government's position. I do not accept the characterisation you painted around the comments I made in this place last year. We have always been seeking broad community support. We certainly achieved that in the survey that was conducted in Hawker around the Wallerberdina Station last year, when support of that level was achieved. But the government is also of the view that a level of support around the 57 per cent level, which was achieved in Kimba early last year, is also indicative of quite broad community support, particularly on an issue that has been very fraught and fractious for our nation for four decades now.

I firmly believe, and the government firmly believes, that we need to find a long-term solution to store our nuclear waste, primarily produced by the world-class facility at Lucas Heights, which produces nuclear medicines that will help to improve the health of, on average, one out of every two Australians during their lifetime. We do need to find a long-term store for that. We're committed to doing that. However, we're also committed to making sure that running a grassroots program that ensures that any decision to place such a facility in a local community is a decision for that community. We will listen to their views through that process. We've been consulting extensively with those communities. The process for a ballot that we've put in place is one aspect of that consultation. We've had officials in Kimba and Hawker for the last year on a weekly basis. We have also conducted surveys with the neighbouring landowners. Obviously, their views are very important. Indigenous stakeholders are extremely important as well. All of these views will be factored into a government decision later this year. (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Patrick, a supplementary question?

Senator PATRICK (South Australia) (14:33): Joseph Stalin once said, 'It's not the people who vote that count; it's the people who count the vote.' Comrade Minister, isn't it the case that by not telling the people of Kimba and Hawker up-frontâ€”
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senators Watt and Abetz, I couldn't hear the question. Please continue after the after the word 'minister', Senator Patrick.

Senator PATRICK: Isn't it the case that, by not telling the people of Kimba and Hawker up-front exactly how their vote will count in this decision, you're leaving it open to claim just about any vote outcome as support for a decision that in reality has already been taken? Isn't it the case that, consistent with the best Stalinist practice, you won't be up-front with the people of Hawker and Kimbaâ€” (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Patrick. I provided some extra time for the question, given the interruption. Senator Canavan, I call you to answer the question in the way it was asked.

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:34): Thank you, Mr President. I maintain that the government has been incredibly up-front and open through this process. As I explained in Kimba and Hawker when I was there around a month ago, any decision that I make as the minister under the National Radioactive Waste Management Act will result in legislative changes to that act. That will, of course, come back to this parliament, so that will be an additional step of accountability and review for that decision-making process. But the government and myselfâ€”one of many ministers who's had responsibility for this actâ€”are simply conducting our responsibilities under the legislative authority that's been given to us by the National Radioactive Waste Management Act, passed, I think, in 2012.

So we'll continue to work with the communities on this. We're very committed to doing this consultation. It's been a great privilege to work with Kimba and Hawker on this, and I look forward to seeing the results of a ballot, hopefully, soon.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Patrick, a final supplementary question.

Senator PATRICK (South Australia) (14:35): Minister, if the Bungala people are successful in their proceedings on foot, their 200 or so negative votes will push the percentage of the yes vote down to the low 50s, possibly even the 40s, which is well short of what you said was credible from a community-support perspective. The Senate inquiry was very critical of the government's engagement in respect of Indigenous people. If you had your time again, would you do things differently or would your Stalinist approach make that totally nugatory?

Senator CANAVAN
( Queensland â€” Minister for Resources and Northern Australia ) ( 14:36 ): I take this decision and this process extremely seriously. As I said, it does relate to the production of life-saving medicines for our country. Obviously, the management of the waste associated with that production is incredibly important. We do a very good job at doing that today but, clearly, we have to make decisions soon, given the capacity constraints at Lucas Heights, about future waste production.

The Bungala people, who Senator Patrick referred to, have initiated action in the Supreme Court of South Australia in relation to the process. I'm not going to comment in detail about something that's before a court, but, suffice to say that I and my department are working constructively with the Bungala people through a conciliation process at the moment. I would hope that we can reach an agreement on a future consultation process, because I'm very committed to working with these local communities to get the best decision for them and for our national interest as well.
Broadband

Senator DEAN SMITH (Western Australiaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:37): My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Fifield. Can the minister update the Senate on measures taken to improve customers' experience of the National Broadband Network?

Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (14:37): Thank you, Senator Smith, for your ongoing interest in the NBN. If I could just quickly cover off on Senator Smith's home state, where the rollout is full steam ahead: over 80 per cent of premises in Western Australia are able to connect to the network and over half a million premises in WA have an active service.

In November last year, the ACCC announced a comprehensive inquiry into wholesale service standards to improve customer experience of the NBN. As a result of those 11 months of work, I'm pleased to advise colleagues that the NBN has, this week, signed an undertaking to pay financial penalties for anything less than a 100 per cent performance in relation to NBN connections, fault rectifications or missed appointments. This means that if your NBN connection doesn't work, if your service is not rectified properly or if an NBN contractor misses an appointment, the NBN will pay. Under section 87B of the Competition and Consumer Act, the NBN will pay the fines as rebates to retailers, who must take reasonable steps to pass these rebates on to businesses and families using the NBN.

Obviously, there is no such thing as a 100 per cent fault-free service. Things will still, from time to time, not be all that we would hope that they would be. But if we're to achieve world's best practice we must set the bar high, and today's announcement does that. In addition, the NBN has also undertaken to commence regular public reporting on the rates of congestion within its fixed wireless network.
Today's announcement is a big win for customers on the NBN. It builds on a range of measures that have been put in place by this government to deliver better broadband.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Smith, a supplementary question.
Senator DEAN SMITH (Western Australiaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:39): Minister, how have the rollout experiences for Australians on the NBN improved?

Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (14:39): I will just, as my point of embarkation, acknowledge that the NBN, under Labor, when they had no customers, connected just 51,000 customers in four years. Under our government, the NBN connects that many customers every two weeks and, according to independent experts, the experience is overwhelmingly good. In March, the ACCC's Rod Sims said that speed delivery was 'better than expected' and that this goes:
â€¦ against the current wisdom that the majority of consumers and businesses are having issues with NBN speeds.
Industry publication CommsDay also reported that if the NBN customer base were a country, it would be ranked top 10 in the world for speed. So this is good news.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Smith, a final supplementary question.
Senator DEAN SMITH (Western Australiaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:40): Can the minister outline some of the key achievements outlined in the NBN Co's 2019 corporate plan?

Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (14:40): The corporate plan demonstrates that the project is on track to deliver for all Australians by 2020. NBN is on track to be cash flow positive. Revenue grew to $2 billion in 2017-18 and is forecast to extend to $5 billion per year from 2021. New pricing has ended fixed line congestion and helped consumers take up higher-speed services. There are 47 per cent of consumers who are now on 50 megabit per second plans or faster. By the end of 2020, 8.1 million homes and businesses will be connected. Investments in consumer experience have driven better services and fewer faults. What this means, practically, for many Australians is that there will be Netflix without buffering, small regional businesses linked to the global economy and remote communities connected digitally to city services. That's the experience that the government is delivering.
Climate Change

Senator LEYONHJELM (New South Wales) (14:41): My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Senator Canavan. Can the minister outline the expected change in greenhouse gas emissions, including from land use change and forestry, in China between 2005 and 2030? What is the percentage change and what is the absolute change in terms of tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:42): I thank Senator Leyonhjelm for his question and for some advanced notice of it. As I'm sure this chamber is aware, the Paris Agreement is a collective response to the global threat of climate change. It has been signed by a number of countries, including China. China's commitment under the agreement is to reduce its emissions intensity as an economy by 60 to 65 per cent of 2005 levels. The advice I have is that China does not have official projections of their 2030 emissions, so I'm unable to provide a specific answer to Senator Leyonhjelm's question. China is, however, one of the largest investors in renewable energy in the world, committing, I think, $130 billion to clean energy technologies, and it is responsible for over half of solar installations in the world. Of course, China is experiencing above average economic growth, which is a good thing for the world. That does, of course, also mean it has growth in emissions and reflects why its commitment is in terms of emissions intensity, not as an absolute number or level of emissions.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Leyonhjelm, a supplementary question.

Senator LEYONHJELM (New South Wales) (14:43): It is probably no surprise to the minister that I actually know the numbers. I'll give them to him afterwards. Can the minister outline the expected change in greenhouse gas emissions between 2005 and 2030 in India, including land-use change and forestry, both in percentage terms and in terms of tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent?

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:44): Like China, India has also ratified the Paris Agreement. Similarly, like China, its commitment is in terms of emissions intensity, at 33 to 35 per cent of its 2005 levels. Like China, India is growing very strongly. In fact, I believe it is the fastest-growing major economy in the world at the moment. So, as it grows and, hopefully, moves to the category of developed nations, its emissions will increase, as will its commitments in terms of its percentage of emissions per economic output, not in terms of absolute number of emissions like Australia.

India is on track to over-achieve its 2020 targets under the previous agreement. I should have mentionedâ€”I think it was remiss of meâ€”that China is also on track to meet its 2020 target. India, likewise, has significant substantial ambitions to increase its renewable capacity by 227 gigawatts, by 2022, and it's on track to achieve that. They are very strongâ€” (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Leyonhjelm, a final supplementary question?

Senator LEYONHJELM (New South Wales) (14:45): The government wants Australian greenhouse gas emissions, between 2005 and 2030, to fall by 26 per cent. My information is that this represents a reduction in absolute terms of 156 tonnes. My calculation is that China's emissions increases over that period will be between 15 and 40 times Australia's. India's will be between 26 and 47 times Australia's emissions. Can the ministerâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Leyonhjelm, your time for asking the question has expired. I'll call Senator Canavan to respond to that asked.

Senator CANAVAN (Queenslandâ€”Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:45): As I did mention, I have received advance warning of this question, so I can provide some information for the senator. First, I will just point out that Australia's commitment to reduce emissions is to reduce it on a budget, from 2021 to 2030, and so the figures I have are slightly different from what Senator Leyonhjelm has just quoted.

I've been advised that our commitment is an amount of 868 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent under that methodology. As I mentioned, we don't have official projections for China's and India's emissions. Indonesia have committed to reduce emissions by 29 to 41 per cent from business as usual. That will lead to 1,692 to 2,037 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions. There is no official emissions profile for Iran.
Members of Parliament: Conduct

Senator McCARTHY (Northern Territory) (14:47): My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Women, Senator Payne. Last week the minister told ABC's 7.30 program, following the Liberal leadership chaos, 'It's clear to me that people were subject to threats and intimidation and bullying.' Does the Minister for Women stand by her statement?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:47): I think the Minister for Women, Minister O'Dwyer, has made her position and her perspective on this very clear. She has raised a number of issues and I don't think she has made any change to those remarks.
The PRESIDENT: Senator McCarthy, a supplementary question.
Senator McCARTHY (Northern Territory) (14:47): The former Minister for Foreign Affairs, and deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Julie Bishop last week said:
When a feisty, amazing woman like Julia Banks says this environment is not for me, don't say 'toughen up princess', say 'enough is enough'.
Has the minister discussed with Prime Minister Morrison concerns about dismissing experiences of bullying?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:48): I think a number of people who have been involved in commentary on this matter have indicated that we don't want to see anywhere in this parliament the sort of behaviour that's been described. I listened to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition this morning doing media on Radio National and on Sky. She certainly made some observations on Radio National about experiences that she has had. Nobody wants to see in this parliament the sort of behaviour that's been described. I have indicated myself that I've agreed with that. I've seen both sides of the chamber and other parts of the parliament deal with these issues over a long period of time. It's not appropriate in any workplace. It is not appropriate here.
The PRESIDENT: Senator McCarthy, a final supplementary question.

Senator McCARTHY (Northern Territory) (14:48): During the week of Liberal leadership chaos, Senator Reynolds said, in relation to the bullying and intimidation that has gone on, she was 'distressed and disturbed by what has happened in my own party'. Is the minister confident that the Prime Ministerâ€”
Government senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Please pause, Senator McCarthy. On my rightâ€”I've constantly asked for silence during questions. That applies to all sides of the chamber. Please continue Senator McCarthy.
Senator McCARTHY: Is the minister confident that the Prime Minister accepts Senator Reynolds' assessment?
Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:49): Mr President, I didn't hear all of Senator McCarthy's question. But one thing I would say, and I will reiterateâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Payne. Senator McCarthy on a point of order?
Senator McCarthy: If I may be able to repeat the question for the ministerâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong?

Senator Wong: Mr President, it's obviously at your discretion, but if a minister is not answering a question because he or she did not hear it, I think it would be reasonable for the senator to repeat it, and I would indicate that it was, on this occasion, because of people behind her interjecting.
The PRESIDENT: I will let Senator Payne continue. I heard the question. If Senator Payne is confident that she can answer the question as askedâ€”
Opposition senators interjectingâ€”

The PRESIDENT: On my left! If there were silence around the chamber, as I and other senators have repeatedly asked for, all ministers would always hear all parts of all questions. There may have been silence on your side on this occasion. It's not always the case.

Senator PAYNE: Perhaps I should have been careful to say that while I didn't hear all of Senator McCarthy's question I do understand that she was making a reference to my friend and colleague Senator Reynolds and some observations she has made. I have responded to both of Senator McCarthy's questions in relation to these issues. They are an unfortunate part of the discussions. I've said that I don't think they have any place, and I would hope that they wouldn't be tolerated by anyone.
Economy

Senator HUME (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:51): My question is also to the Minister representing the Minister for Jobs and Industrial Relations, Senator Payne. Can the minister inform the Senate about the work the coalition government is doing to support workers and small businesses?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:51): I thank Senator Hume for her question. The government is working very hard to ensure that workers are helped to keep more of their own hard-earned money. We have provided tax relief to 10 million people already, and there is more to come in that regard. The net result is that the money is where it belongs: in workers' pockets. The government is also helping small businesses to grow, to invest, to hire more staff and to pay more wages by cutting taxes for businesses with a turnover of up to $50 million. Just today a bill to further extend the small business instant asset write-off measure passed through the Senate, meaning that small businesses can continue to access the red tape reduction and the cashflow boost that come with being able to write off assets of up to $20,000.

There has been a very important consequence of the government's strong economic plan, and that is jobs. A job means opportunities. It means fulfilment and it means financial security. As we know, this government has been deliveringâ€”more than 400,000 jobs created in 2017, which was a record, and around 340,000 jobs created in the 2017-18 financial year, which was the largest financial year increase in more than a decade. And there are more young people at work, over 95,000 of them finding employment in the 2017-18 year alone. That is the best result in almost 30 years. This government is committed to protecting and supporting workers and small business, and we'll continue to lay a platform that allows the economy to prosper and that gets more Australians into more jobs.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Hume, a supplementary question.

Senator HUME (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:53): Can the minister advise of how the government's legislative agenda will help to further protect the rights of workers and small businesses?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:53): I thank Senator Hume for her supplementary question. We know that employer associations and unions in particular have a privileged position in the industrial relations system and that their members place a great deal of trust in them. But lawless behaviour by some of these organisations and their officials not only harms their members but also harms small business and the economy. The government's ensuring-integrity bill is before the Senate right now, and it's crucial to making sure that small business and workers are protected from that sort of behaviour, including by those in unions who might take the law into their own hands. There are, of course, some that we're very familiar with, and we include unions like the CFMMEU in that. They are poster boys for that sort of behaviour. To date they've accumulated around $1,600 million in court-ordered penalties for breaking the law, but that doesn't seem to be a deterrentâ€”it's only members' fees, after allâ€” (Timeexpired)
The PRESIDENT: Senator Hume, a final supplementary question?
Senator HUME (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Government Whip in the Senate) (14:54): Can the minister advise whether there are any key risks to ensuring integrity in registered organisations?

Senator PAYNE (New South Walesâ€”Minister for Foreign Affairs) (14:54): I think there are some key risks, so Senator Hume's question is a very good one. I think they're mostly sitting on the other side of the chamber, because, unfortunately, we see that the Labor Party won't support the government's very sensible reforms.
Opposition senators interjectingâ€”

Senator PAYNE: Of course the volume goes up on the other side, because they don't like to hear this. They don't support the government's reforms because they are completely beholden to those who are their mates in the union movement, particularly the CFMEU. In fact, what they should do, if they were sensible, and given what's already on the public record, is disavow the CFMEU. They should welcome the opportunity that the integrity legislation will give them to get rid of the bad eggs who spoil the union movement for good workers. That's what the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Amendment (Ensuring Integrity) Bill 2017 would do. But they can't do that, because they're under the union's thumb. The Leader of the Opposition needs their support and needs their leadership votes. He continues to benefit from their millions of dollars in donations. (Timeexpired)
Members of Parliament: Conduct
Senator KENEALLY (New South Wales) (14:56): My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Cormann. Last week, Senator Gichuhi told Radio National's RNDrive program:
I will detail my experience not only with the PM's spill, because this is a culture, this is a systematic kind of issue.
Last night, Prime Minister Morrison told ABC's 7.30 program that Senator Gichuhi:
â€¦ told me very plainly that she was not bullied by anybody here in Canberra â€¦

Given the Prime Minister's willingness to make public his conversation with Senator Gichuhi, did Senator Gichuhi tell Prime Minister Morrison about her experience of bullying within the Liberal Party?
Government senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order on my right! For the sixth or seventh time, I'm going to ask for silence during questions so I can rule on subsequent, partly inevitable, points of order.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (14:57): I think I've canvassed this issue on a number of occasions this week. As I've said on every occasion, of course, the Prime Minister, myself and others engage with all of our colleagues. We talk to all of our colleagues on a regular basis. We, of course, care for the welfare of every member of our team, and the Prime Minister will continue to do so. He will continue to work with all of the members of his team to ensure that we continue to make Australia stronger, keep the Australian economy strong, keep Australians safe and keep Australians together. Only the Labor Party would think that a leader of a parliamentary party could gag their MPs. Maybe the Labor Party does these things. In our party, we don't gag our MPs.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Keneally, on a point of order?

Senator Keneally: My point of order is on relevance. The minister has strayed far from the question. He is not even attempting to be relevant. I specifically asked: given that the Prime Minister has made public his conversation with Senator Gichuhi, what did Senator Gichuhi tell the Prime Minister about her experience of bullying within the Liberal Party?

The PRESIDENT: You have restated the question and reminded the minister of it. I will remind you, Senator Keneally, that the minister is also entitled to address other parts of your question. As long as he is directly relevant to thoseâ€”
Senator Keneally: What part of my question was it?

The PRESIDENT: Are you going to let me finish? As long as the minister is directly relevant to part of the question asked, I cannot direct him how to answer it. I've said you have reminded him of the end of your question. I call the minister to continue.

Senator CORMANN: As I was saying, only the Labor Party would think that a leader of a party could gag their MPs. On our side of the chamber, we actually believe in freedom of speech and we believe in exercising our consciences. These values are central to how we operate.
Opposition senators interjectingâ€”
Senator CORMANN: I hear the Labor Party jumping up and down. Where was the Labor Party to protect Senator Singh from the bullying of Labor preselectors in Tasmania? Where was the Labor Partyâ€”
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Order on my right. This is why I like to be able to hear the question. Senator Wong, on a point of order?
Senator Wong: On direct relevance: if he wants us to start talking about Senator Macdonald, we will.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Cormann, I remind you of the question and call you to continue.

Senator CORMANN: As I've said a number of times now, there is no place for bullying in any workplace. Senator Payne has also made that very clear on behalf of the government. But I would say, though, that I've read reports from former Labor senator Margaret Reynolds, who saidâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Cormann. Senator Wong, on a point of order?
Senator Wong: This isâ€”
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Can I hear Senator Wong's point of order?

Senator Wong: The point of order is direct relevance. Senator Cormann was asked a question which went to a discussion between the Prime Minister and Senator Gichuhi. This has nothing to do with that. He may not want to tell us. He may not want to tell us about the conversationâ€”then he should sit down.

The PRESIDENT: The minister was halfway through a sentence. I'm listening very carefully. I remind the minister of the question, as he has been on a number of occasions by senators on my left, and ask him to continue.
Senator CORMANN: I've already answered the question. I'm providing further background. When asked how the union heavyweights that have, of course, been defeated byâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Cormann. Senator Wong, on a point of order?
Senator Wong: This is an abuse of question time, Mr President, and I ask you to sit the minister down or tell him to be directly relevant. This is beyond the pale for the Leader of the Governmentâ€”

The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, when you raised your previous point of order, the minister had got about four words into an issue, which he has continued. Senator Cormann, I ask you to return to the question.

Senator CORMANN: As I've indicated, I've already answered the question, but I am concerned that somehow there's one standard for us and another standard for the Labor Party. Show and tell, is how they enforceâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, Senator Cormann. I'll call Senator Collins, who was first on her feet.

Senator Jacinta Collins: Again, the point of order is direct relevance. We have heard this minister attempt to go to other matters. Any of us could stand here and go through a range of preselections if we chose to. There are no double standards. No-one is asking about the long list of senators on that side who have lost their preselectionsâ€”

The PRESIDENT: Order! I'm going to rule on this now. When the Senate inserted the term 'directly' before 'relevant' it narrowed the range of ways in which ministers can answer. Minister, I ask you to return to the question, because additional information must be directly relevant to the question as well.
Senator CORMANN: I'm just showing the double standard. I'm sure that Senator Singh was gently eased out of her position.
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Wong, on a point of order?

Senator Wong: This is utterly contemptibleâ€”on direct relevance. You've asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate on four occasions to return to the question, and he has completely ignored you.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Williams, on the point of order?
Senator Williams: Because of the interruption, can I move an extension to the answer for Senator Cormann?
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, I had asked the minister twiceâ€”
Senator Wong interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, please. Senator Cormann, I'll ask you to be directly relevant to the question. That material, in my viewâ€”
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order, on my right and left! That material, in my view, is not directly relevant to the question.
Senator CORMANN: As I indicated, we care for our members. It doesn't seem that the Labor Party cares for theirs.
Senator Wong interjectingâ€”
Senator Jacinta Collins interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Order, Senator Wong and Senator Collins, Senator Keneally is on her feet. Senator Keneally, a supplementary question?

Senator KENEALLY (New South Wales) (15:03): Yesterday Senator Gichuhi announced she had decided not to name bullies in the Senate because, 'The Prime Minister has taken up the issue.' What additional action has the Prime Minister agreed to take to assure Senator Gichuhi that he has taken up the issue of bullying and intimidation within the Liberal Party?
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Macdonald, on a point of order?

Senator Ian Macdonald: Mr President, you asked for silence while questions are being asked. All the way through the last question, Senator Wong, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, was interjecting and making it difficult for me to hear her rival's question.
The PRESIDENT: On the point of order, Senator Wong?
Senator Wong: Mr President, I thought I heard something unparliamentary, and I raised it across the chamber rather than put it on the Hansard. If he wants me to put it on the Hansard, I will.

The PRESIDENT: Order! On that point of order, you've reminded the Senate of my constant request for silence during questions, Senator Macdonald. I was taking notes and could hear the question. I will call the minister to answer it. Had you concluded your question, Senator Keneally?
Senator KENEALLY: I'm happy to restate it.
The PRESIDENT: The minister is confident he heard it, and so am I.

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (15:04): I actually answered a question that was pretty well the same question yesterday. As I've indicated to you, we do have a process through the whips, who have a primary responsibility in terms of dealing with pastoral care issues, as appropriate, as was also acknowledged by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition today. But ultimately the Prime Minister recognises that the buck stops with him. As I've said in response to the primary question, the Prime Minister always has a keen interest in the welfare of every single member of his team, and he continues, and will continue, to engage with every single memberâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Senator Cameron?
Senator Cameron: A point of order, on direct relevanceâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Do not ask me to instruct the minister how to answer a question, Senator Cameron.
An honourable senator: You've got to hear his point of order.
The PRESIDENT: I'll hear your point of order, butâ€”
Senator Cameron: Can I finish?
The PRESIDENT: Senator Cameron, there's not normally a lack of your voice in the chamber at question time. Go on.

Senator Cameron: Thank you. This is on direct relevance. There was one question: what action has the Prime Minister taken to assure Senator Gichuhi that he has taken up the issue of bullying and intimidation within the Liberal Party?
The PRESIDENT: Senator Cameron, the minister was being directly relevant to the question as askedâ€”absolutely.

Senator CORMANN: And remaining directly relevant to the question asked: the essence of that point of order just now by Senator Cameron is that they believe that, if there are contests and conflicts in the context of contested positions in the Liberal Party, it's bullying, but when somebody gets kicked out of the Labor Party it is all done with gentle care! We, of course, have the evidence, from none other than former Labor senator Margaret Reynolds, that the wayâ€” (Timeexpired)
Honourable senators interjectingâ€”
The PRESIDENT: I was actually calling the minister to order, and I think his microphone went silent because the time for the answer had expired. Senator Keneally, a final supplementary question.

Senator KENEALLY (New South Wales) (15:06): Has the Prime Minister agreed to intervene in the South Australian Liberal preselection or make any other appointment to ensure Senator Gichuhi does not detail her experience of bullying within the Liberal Party?

Senator CORMANN (Western Australiaâ€”Minister for Finance and the Public Service, Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (15:06): I have been asked about preselection, and I am pleased to confirm for the Senate that I actually wrote a reference for my good friend and valued colleague Senator Gichuhi. But, given that I am asked a question about preselection, let me say again: how didâ€”
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senator Wong on a point of order?
Senator Wong: The question is whether or not the Prime Minister has offered any assurances in relation to preselection to Senator Gichuhiâ€”that is the question.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Wong, the minister was turning to the issue of preselection. He has been speaking for 20 seconds and he has 40 seconds remaining.

Senator CORMANN: In the Liberal Party, preselections aren't handled like they are in the Labor Party. In the Liberal Party, preselections are democratic processes. In the Labor Party, of course, outcomes are enforced with a show and tellâ€”so says former Labor senator Margaret Reynolds when explaining how Senator Singh was relegated to the fourth position on Labor's Senate ticket in Tasmania.
The PRESIDENT: Senator Cormann?
Senator Cormann: I ask that further questions be placed on the NoticePaper.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS
debateinfo.type: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

p.span: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS
Prime Minister
Senator CAROL BROWN (Tasmania) (15:08): I move:

That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Finance and the Public Service (Senator Cormann) to a question without notice asked by Senator Polley today relating to the Goods and Services Tax.

Today the report in TheMercury, my home state of Tasmania's local Hobart newspaper, really tells the whole story about the relationship between this federal government and the Tasmanian state government. For quite a while now, the Tasmanian federal Labor team have been saying that the federal Tasmanian Liberal representatives up here weren't doing enough to ensure that Tasmania would be able to get its fair share of GST. And the report that's in the paper today really shows that the team here is lacking in their ability to actually get any projects or funding for the state of Tasmania.

What followed today was a statement put out by Minister Gutwein, the Tasmanian Treasurer, that those weren't the words used. But he hasn't denied that there was some sort of robust discussion, nor has he denied that the former Prime Minister, Mr Turnbull, had to step in and negotiate with the Tasmanian Treasurer and the Tasmanian Premier. What we've seen today with the statement from Minister Gutwein, the Tasmanian Treasurer, is that the best he can say about the GST deal is that, on face value, it is a good one for Tasmania. The deal was announced months ago, but Peter Gutwein apparently hasn't seen the detail.
Senator Cormann interjectingâ€”

Senator CAROL BROWN: What is concerning, Senator Cormann, is the fact that we had a Treasurerâ€”now the Prime Ministerâ€”with complete disdain for the state of Tasmania. We have Tasmanian Liberal representatives that haven't been able to push the case for Tasmania.

It's not only in the GST situation that we find this happening. Time and time again we've found that there isn't strong representation from the Tasmanian Liberal team up here. They're too busy playing games and too busy being involved in bringing down a Prime Minister. We know the head of the Tasmanian Liberal team was part of the show that started the destabilisation of Mr Turnbull and brought down Mr Turnbull's prime ministership. We know that. Senator Abetz knows that; he leads this team. He's too busy doing things like thatâ€”carrying grudges and bringing down a serving Prime Ministerâ€”instead of doing the job he's actually up here for.
And then the grubby tactics of yesterday, when he cast aspersions on women in the ALP. It was a disgrace. He may not like quotas, but there are other people that are in his partyâ€”
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Brown, please resume your seat. Senator Wong?
Senator Wong: Madam Deputy President, Senator Abetz has just called us the quota girls. I'm asking him to withdraw 'quota girls'. I think the time has passed for that kind of terminology.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Abetz, Senator Wong has asked you to withdraw. I ask you in the interests of debate and generosity to withdraw those remarks.
Senator Abetz: I categorically reject that that term is in any way unparliamentary according to all the standards, but I acceptâ€”
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Abetz, I did not suggest it was unparliamentaryâ€”
Senator Abetz: If I can finish, Madam Deputy President?

The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Abetz, please resume your seat. I want to make sure that what I said was clearly understood. I did not imply it was unparliamentary. I did suggest, in the spirit of generosity, that you might withdraw it. Please resume.

Senator Abetz: Madam Deputy President, if you wouldn't have interrupted me, that was exactly where I was going, and I assume you would have known that that was where I was going. Accordingly, I withdraw.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Abetz. I was simply making clear that I had not suggested the comment that you made was unparliamentary.
Senator Abetz: On the point of order, Madam Deputy President, if I may?
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Yes?

Senator Abetz: When somebody raises a point of order requesting something be withdrawn under the standing orders it is on the basis that it is unparliamentary. Therefore, for me to make that preamble to my withdrawal was highly appropriate, with great respect.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: I think we will disagree on that, Senator Abetz. Senator Brown, please continue.

Senator CAROL BROWN: Thank you. What we saw in the report in theMercury today on the Prime Minister's behaviour was a slur on every Tasmanian. Quite frankly, the Prime Minister should apologise. We've had a discussion about whether they were the exact words used. That's really meaningless. What is completely apparent is the attitude of this Prime Minister towards Tasmania, and that is a problem for Tasmania. We know that the Tasmanian Premier and the Tasmanian Treasurer have an issue with this government through Prime Minister Morrison. It was there when he was the Treasurer. We now know it was there, and it will continue to be there unless our Liberal Tasmanian senators start standing up for Tasmania. They haven't done so. We've had cuts to hospitals, we've had cuts to schools, we've hadâ€”
Senator Abetz: False, falseâ€”
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order!

Senator CAROL BROWN: Look, Senator Abetz can say things are false but we know they are not false. We can see it. We can see it in our schools. We can see it in the crisis in our hospitalâ€” (Timeexpired)

Senator ABETZ (Tasmania) (15:15): The people of Tasmania have been exceptionally well served by the coalition government, especially in recent years. The track record speaks for itself: the irrigation schemes that are currently being built in Tasmania, the Midland Highway upgrade, the Hobart Airport upgrade, the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme for our exports and so the list goes on. The falsehood, and one has to assume now given the overwhelming public evidence, the deliberate falsehood of seeking to peddle that our schools and hospitals have been cut is simply unsustainable. The facts speak for themselves. There have been considerable increases in funding in both the health and education sectors. It is absolutely clear, and on the record, in each and every budget that the coalition has delivered over the past five years. And yet the Australian Labor Party will continue to come in here and go to the public seeking to peddle a tissue of lies to try to scare people. They did it successfully, I must confess, at the last election with their 'Mediscare' campaign. Completely false, completely untrue and one wonders how they sleep at night knowing that they have gained seats through the peddling of misinformation.

How unself-aware can a senator be when a Labor Senator, such as Senator Carol Brown, gets up and says that supposedly some of us are more concerned about other issues when all she had to do was look over her left shoulder and look at the demise of her Tasmanian Labor Senate colleague Senator Singh. And who controls the division of the Tasmanian Labor Party? None other than Senator Carol Brown and her friends. Good luck to her. That is the nature of politics. It is a tough game, but, please don't come in here and assert things when you yourself, Senator Brown, have been engaged in such machinations that have seen the demotion of Senator Lisa Singh.

That is what the Labor Party want me and the coalition to concentrate on, the petty politics. What we on this side are concentrating on is success for Tasmania, courtesy of the Tasmanian Liberal Senate team, the Tasmanian Liberal government and the commitment of the ministry to all things Tasmanian. That is why the GST deal that was gained for Tasmania will see the delivery of an extra $100-plus million to my home state. Unlike the Australian Labor Party leader, who goes to Western Australia and says, 'You have been dudded. We will give you more,' and then comes to Tasmania and asserts, 'I will give Tasmania just as much as ever before.' The GST isn't a magic puddling. If somebody gets more somebody else has to get less. That is where the numbers never stack up for the Australian Labor Party. That's why they always run deficits and that's why they always increase debt, because they do not have the capacity or the honesty to level with the Australian people and say, 'If somebody gets more money, it may well mean that somebody else gets less money.'

However, Treasurer Morrison and the finance minister were able to negotiate and develop a GST deal that, in fact, sees the state of Tasmania over $100 million better off. And somehow that is a failure on my part?

Well, if an extra $100 million for the state of Tasmania is a failure, I will wear that failure just as much as when we got the extra money for the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme, the Hobart airport, the irrigation scheme, the Midland Highway and the jobs and investment packages. If they are all failures, I will wear them as failures.

The great news is that, since we got into government, the unemployment rate has gone from 8.1 per cent to below six per cent. That is the good economic news. But even better than the economic news is the social news that there are now thousands of extra Tasmanians in gainful employment because of the policies of the federal and state Liberal governments, working together to ensure that that abysmal record of unemployment is wiped off the slate of Tasmania. (Timeexpired)

Senator BILYK (Tasmania) (15:20): Today in question time there was, I would say, an almost deceitful attempt to get away from the truth in the minister's answers in regard to the questions we were asking on the GST issues. The Prime Minister's behaviour reported this morning is a slur on every Tasmanian, and Mr Morrison really should apologise. He's taking Tasmanians for granted. Just because he's got no federal members from there in the House of Representatives doesn't mean he should ignore us or treat us as any less. It certainly doesn't mean that he should be rude about it. Whether the actual potty-mouthed comments were said or not, he did say that we were a 'mendicant' state and he really should take that back. That is implying that we are just beggars. We have the right to make sure that the people of Tasmania are looked after, and the Liberal senators on that side of the chamber should be doing just that as well.

Mr Morrison is completely out of touch, and his smugness is going to be the downfall of him. Let me just say this: he is not listening to the people of Tasmania at all. He will end up without any House of Representatives members from Tasmania yet again at the next election. That's my prediction. The people of Tasmania don't like to be (a) insulted and (b) taken as mugs. In regard to the GST issue, Prime Minister Scott Morrison and the Tasmanian Treasurer, Peter Gutwein, clearly disagreed over the dud GST deal, and what it's exposed to us are great divisions in the Liberal Party. It's clear that Peter Gutwein believed the GST deal was defective in some way and that there was something not right with it, but what is also clear is that Premier Hodgman rolled over and signed up anyway. Today's Hobart Mercury newspaper reported:
MALCOLM Turnbull was forced to sideline Scott Morrison in critical GST negotiations after his then treasurer allegedly abused his Tasmanian counterpart Peter Gutwein in an expletive-laden tirade.

The Mercury understands the Tasmanian Liberals were still so concerned about Mr Morrison's attitude towards their state during negotiations that they asked their counterparts in Canberra to counsel Mr Morrison before he did media here following the deal being done.

This is an amazing assessment of Mr Morrison's shortcomings as Treasurer. It's a stark example of why he shouldn't be Prime Minister. We haven't actually heard why he should be Prime Minister. We haven't actually heard why Prime Minister Turnbull was rolled. We can't get any answers out of anyone on those things. As for Mr Morrison telling people to just get on with it, we are not going to just get on with it. We want some answers. We want to know why it all happened.

But while Mr Morrison might deny the language that he used, it's very clear, as I said, that his attitude to Tasmania and to Tasmanians is problematical. It's very problematical. It's notable that the Tasmanian Liberal Treasurer is, as I said, yet to deny the Prime Minister was sidelined from GST discussions because of his conduct. So Mr Gutwein hasn't come out and said, 'No, that didn't happen.' Mr Morrison is out of touch, he's smug and he's condescending. I don't think, in general, people like that. He might think he's being a leader, but most of us think he's just playing a bit of a game. He was the last man standing after many, many iterations through that week. And no-one voted for Mr Morrison or his illegitimate government.

We know that Tasmanians feel that the economy isn't working for them. They talk to us all the time. The people are worried about passing on a worse deal to their kids. This is the first generation where that has started to happen. In previous generations people have been able to pass on to their kids better deals than they had themselves. Well, this is no longer happening, under the Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison government. Mr Morrison and the Libs have spent five years cutting the essential services that working Tasmanians rely on while giving tax handouts to the top end of town. Let's look at just how much Mr Morrison actually cares about Tasmania. When he was the Treasurer he visited Tasmania onceâ€”just once. (Timeexpired)

Senator PATERSON (Victoria) (15:25): On the question of the GST, I am very proud to rise to contribute to this debate as a Victorian senator, because it is indeed Victoria that can stand very proud and tall as one of the states in the federation that has been a net contributor to the federation since Federation. In fact, casting my eyes around the chamber right now, I believe that I and Senator Hume and you, Mr President, and Senator Fifield are the only senators in the chamber at this very moment who can proudly say that they represent a state that has been a net contributor to the federation since Federation.

Senator Bilyk is most unkind to her fellow Tasmanians. On my recent trips to Tasmania for the by-election, to support the great Brett Whiteley for Tasmania's state election, what I observed from Tasmaniaâ€”and I know Senator Cameron is a frequent and fond visitor to Tasmania alsoâ€”is that Tasmania is booming. And it is no wonder that Tasmania is booming, under the twin leadership of a coalition government here in Canberra and the outstanding leadership of the Hodgman government in Tasmania. Tasmania's doing well because it's got a good state government that is focused on free enterprise, jobs and economic growth, not on environmental radicalism or locking up the state. Tasmania is doing well because it's got a federal government that is focused on the economy, jobs and prosperity and a federal government that is supportive of Tasmania.

We have here in this chamber a very dedicated, very eloquent and very passionate team of Tasmanian coalition senators who work very hard every day to ensure that their state's interests are well protected. We have my friend Senator Duniam. We have Senator Abetz, who made a contribution to this debate earlier; Senator Bushby, our Chief Government Whip; Senator Colbeck, the only frontbencher from Tasmania; and of course our most recent new addition, Senator Martin, our new Nationals colleague from Tasmania. They are a strong, united team and they're effective at advocating for Tasmania. The evidence is clear for all to seeâ€”and not just in the new GST distribution, although that is a very important recent edition.

This debate seeks to impugn the integrity, the motives and the contribution of our Prime Minister. But it was of course our Prime Minister who, not that long ago, as Treasurer, devised a solution to the GST distribution problem that had eluded all previous governments. This is not a new problem, but it is a problem that this government and Prime Minister Morrison, as Treasurer, took head-on and addressed. And he addressed it in such a way thatâ€”yesâ€”dealt with the very valid concerns of my Western Australian colleagues, who have been for years raising the problems of the GST distribution and the way in which their state has been disadvantaged. It effectively dealt with their concerns but did so without taking anything at all away from any other state.

I have a table here, published in the FinancialReview in July this year, which summarises the boost of the GST distribution pool by state out to 2026-27, the time period over which the solution is proposed. This is how each state fares under that solution: $351 million of net benefit to New South Wales; $425 million of benefit to Victoria; $518 million of benefit to Queensland; $3.3 billion of benefit to Western Australia; $257 million of benefit to South Australia; and $112 million of benefit to Tasmania. There is even $46 million of benefit going to the ACT, and there is $189 million of benefit going to the Northern Territory. So every state and every territory, from Tasmania to Western Australia included, will be better off under the GST distribution solution devised by our former Treasurer and now Prime Minister, Scott Morrison. He has been very unfairly maligned in this debate.

Also unfairly maligned is the Tasmanian Liberal Senate team. Not only have they secured a strong GST deal for their state; they have secured a range of other generous supports for Tasmania, which, in the 2018-19 budget, amounted to $3.8 billion. That included, of course, the GST disbursements to the state of $2Â½ billion but also specific-purpose funding of $1.3 billion; record funding for schools of $446 million, which is an increase of $7.2 million since the last budget; and record infrastructure funding of $142 million, which is an increase of $27.3 million since the last budget. Tasmania is doing well and Australia is doing well under this Prime Minister.

Senator SINGH (Tasmania) (15:30): The revelation today of a clear disagreement between the Prime Minister, Scott Morrison, during his time as Treasurer, and the Tasmanian Treasurer, Peter Gutwein, over the dud GST deal for Tasmania has once again exposed the out-of-control divisions within the Liberal Party. We all saw that on display only a fortnight ago, but now, through a leak, we have again seen an incredible division between the Tasmanian Liberals at the state level and this new Prime Minister and the federal Liberals.

What does this mean for the future of Tasmania? What does it mean when we have a Tasmanian government that does not get along with its federal counterparts and, in fact, when it does not get along with this Prime Minister? There are real concerns now about what this whole affair means for a number of Tasmania's vital services. What does it mean for the City Deal, what does it mean for Macquarie Point, what does it mean for essential services like our health and hospital crisis when we have a Prime Minister who has shown such contempt for Tasmania? All Tasmanians today would have woken up incredibly worried by the fact that we have, as leaked in TheMercury, a Prime Minister who has shown his complete contempt.

If this dud deal that the state Liberals rolled over for was not bad enough, it's now clear we have a Prime Minister who does not care about Tasmania as a state. To allegedly refer to our state as 'mendicant' is just absolutely abhorrent. We all know that this refers to a telephone call that occurred between the now Prime Minister and the state Treasurer, Peter Gutwein. Prime Minister Morrison, who was then Treasurer, indicated that Tasmanians are, in effect, beggarsâ€”that we are, in effect, beggars. It is absolutely abhorrent for the Prime Minister of this country to refer to Tasmania as beggars. It tells us what this Prime Minister thinks of us, what he thinks of Tasmanians, behind closed doors.

We know what he thinks of Tasmanians, because he has been to Tasmania only four times in the past 10 years, and one of those times was during the recent Braddon by-electionâ€”once in this term of government and in his time as Treasurer. I think that says it all. For the Prime Minister to refer to Tasmanians as beggars is deeply offensive. It also proves exactly what has always been suspected, which is that this GST deal was designed for Western Australia at the expense of Tasmania. No Tasmanian has ever been fooled by that. It has been a dud deal since day one; it has been a dud deal since then. But then again 'how dud?' we don't know, because the Treasurer of Tasmania himself has said that he has taken it on face value. He has taken this deal on face valueâ€”a deal that has an effect on Tasmania's bottom line, Tasmania's budget, and how we deliver our services. He said months ago that he still hadn't seen the detail.

There goes the relationship. That shows you how close the relationship is between the Tasmanian Treasurer and the then federal Treasurer, now Prime Minister. It does not bode well for the future of Tasmania under this state Liberal government, and it does not bode well for the future of Tasmania under this federal coalition government under Scott Morrison. The sooner there is an election in this country, the better. And the sooner we vote this joke of a government out of this country, the betterâ€”so that states like Tasmania can get a decent government that cares about all Australians, including Tasmanians; so that Tasmanians do get their fair share of the GST; so that we can be respected; and so that we can deliver the services that Tasmanians expect. The title 'beggar' used by this Prime Minister is absolutely offensive.
Question agreed to.
PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
Senator REYNOLDS (Western Australiaâ€”Assistant Minister for Home Affairs) (15:36): I seek leave to make a personal explanation resulting from some of the debate at question time.

Senator REYNOLDS: On 23 August this year, I rose in the Senate to address my concerns about the behaviour of some in parliament during our leadership challenges. My speech then was in response to questions without notice by members of the opposition at question time that day. Despite significant discussion in this chamber and in the media, I stand by my comments on that day.

Today I did comment publicly for the first and last time on these stories of bullying and intimidation which continue to be aired, sadly, by Labor women in this chamber and also by the media. A number of my colleagues have also addressed these issuesâ€”very senior colleagues in my party. The Australian people have made it abundantly clear to me and, I'm sure, to all people in this chamber that they are sick and tired of hearing politicians talk about themselves. I share their sentiments. I strongly believe that the correct forum to address these concerns is via robust and constructive discussion within the Liberal parliamentary party processes, not in the media and not in this chamber. I am very confident and very comfortable that the Prime Minister and our whips are taking the appropriate action in this process, which, again, I firmly believe is something that is best dealt with internally, because (1) the Australian people deserve better and (2) if we are to seek genuine outcomes, like in any other organisation, we need to deal with these matters ourselves.

I'm incredibly honoured to have been appointed as the Assistant Minister for Home Affairs in the Morrison government. Over the past two weeks my focus has been on my new responsibilities and seeing firsthand the amazing work that the men and women of the Department of Home Affairs, the Australian Border Force and Emergency Management Australia have been doing. These men and women, many of whom are serving the nation in uniform, are serving with distinction. They are securing our borders; they are keeping Australians safe, and they are ensuring that, as a nation, we are well prepared for a challenging upcoming emergency-management season. The last thing those men and women need is their ministers sitting there, in the public, talking about themselves and not addressing the important issues that they are dealing with.

As I said, it was extremely disappointing to see the Labor Party again making very cheap political capital out of this issue in this chamber, criticising the way that we, as Liberal Party women, choose to deal with this issue and exploiting it in this chamber. What my colleagues and I are doing is exactly what we have done in relation to the Labor Party. When the Labor Party has exhibited appalling behaviour towards people on my side of the chamber, we haven't done what those opposite have been doing in this chamber today and to Minister Nash last year. When these issues have arisen on occasion, in terms of bad behaviour by those opposite, on our sideâ€”I certainly have not ever publicised the issues or brought them into the political arena here in this chamber. In fact, sitting here today and listening to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Wong, I was incredibly disappointed because, when issues have happened and she has had cause to apologise to me and others for the behaviour of her team, we have dealt with it privately, not publicly.

When it has been public, Senator Cameron, we have discussed it publicly but we have not brought it into this chamber. I firmly believe that in politics in this chamber and in any organisation in Australia, if we are truly to deal with the issues faced by many women in the workplace then cheapening them through theatrical politics here in question time doesn't assist the women in my party, doesn't assist the women in this chamber and it certainly does not assist the women in any workplace in this country. This is the last time I will be discussing this publicly. I want to make it very clear that it is not because I am giving up the fight; it is because I believe the appropriate way to do that, to get meaningful change, is within my party. Those opposite, I would ask and I would plead: if you want to see a better future for women in this chamber, stop politicising it and making it even harder for us on this side to deal with it. Thank you, Mr President.
PETITIONS

The
Clerk: A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

subdebateinfo.title: Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme

p.span: Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme
To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme 'BSPVES' is now unnecessarily perpetuating the single greatest barrier for Tasmania limiting the growth of population, investment and jobs.
The scheme and associated measures were intended to remove this barrier by making Bass Strait 'a part of the National Highway'.
Bass Strait is already more than adequately federally funded.
In 1996, the 'BSPVES' was introduced following a public campaign for Bass Strait transport equality.
In 2001-2 a major change was made, destroying the original intention of the scheme.

Your petitioner Peter Brohier, asks that the Senate, call on the Prime Minister to use his best endeavors to restore the original purpose by causing Bass Strait passenger ferry fares to be brought into line with the cost of land-based National Highway travel.
A lowering of Bass Strait passenger fares to the cost of highway travel would extend the Hume Highway to Hobart and work a social an economic miracle across two states.
This huge interstate, inter-capital infrastructure link can connect our nation in days, without even one kilometer of highway needed.
There is every resource, including sea highway policy, unused shipping capacity and federal funding, in place now to restore equalisation.
Given the history of Bass Strait ferry transport over the last two decades, it seems unlikely, without further Federal intervention, that a ferry service will ever move people at highway equivalence.

The current skewed access reduces the passenger vehicle ratio, acts against a volume service and uses the BSPVES inefficiently when compared with highway equivalence. This approach hinders the growth of many of the largest sectors of the Tasmanian economy.
It seems capable of mainly growing the accommodation sector in Tasmania with a small trickle down impact on the rest.
Petition PN 0352 House of Representatives and the Ministerial Response tabled on the 20th August 2018 and appearing in Hansard are relevant.
The Ministerial response confirms that under the 'BSPVES', the intention of providing highway equalisation for people movement to and from Tasmania by sea was abandoned in 2002.

The Coalition's announcement in 2001-2 indicated an intention to expand the equalisation scheme, not to destroy it. The Ministerial response confirms that despite this, the BSPVES scheme continued to maintain the word 'equalisation' in its title.
Whilst the funding mechanism changed from 'highway equivalence' to CPI, the equalisation intention of the BSPVES need not have changed . It did.
Unfortunately, the apparent intent of filling ferries in winter was the change in objective that destroyed equalisation. This is even questionable.
The Ministerial response refers to substantial federal funding under the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme 'TFES' and the BSPVES. These
schemes are said to be now aimed at lowering the cost of transport for both freight and people.
The response failed to acknowledge that a competitive market for freight under the 1976 TFES brings the freight cost to shippers down. The same does not seem to be the case for people.

Using the BSPVES to value add to travel or meet the needs of those seeking leisure holidays in Tasmania may satisfy the needs of a relatively small accommodation sector. This seems to be the overriding priority of sea travel rather than low fares.
Under the BSPVES the cost of travel continues to be set by a single operator, hourly or daily, at any level it chooses. Vital and expected sea based competition has not arisen.

After 2002, 'equalisation' should have been maintained, in the absence of competition, by a community service obligation imposed on the BSPVES and or, by placing a condition on the use of the BSPVES by only ferry operators willing to maintain sufficient equalized fares as are necessary on such a critical route.

Our nation doesn't destroy other interstate, inter-capital highways within a few years of their inception to meet the needs of a connecting ferry or punt, or a few special interest groups in one state. Why do so here? Why announce an expansion of the equalisation scheme, then remove an equalisation formula from Ministerial directives.

I was chairman of the original National Sea Highway Committee 'NSHC'. Without that committee, and its predecessor, the Committee for Bass Strait Transport Equality, which I also chaired, there would be no BSPVES. These committees started in the mid to early 1990's.
The NSHC was possibly the most influential committee of the time. It represented many major interests across Tasmania, and on the mainland.
The vision and aims of these committees should not now be overridden.
The BSPVES funding was always uncapped and demand driven. It continues to this day . It was a serious amount of money necessary for closing the gap in an interstate transport link.
It was accompanied by written policy created by the Coalition.

The BSPVES was not about replacing underutilized shipping by the purchase of even more new ferries, value adding to trips, offering a free or reduced priced transportation of the shell of a car, prioritizing the needs of ferry operators over highway travel, supporting seasonal fare variation, stressing the importance of one-way visitation, providing leisure holidays with a car, increasing costs of transport, promoting longer holidays in just Tasmania, largely ignoring the impact on Victoria, ignoring the world definition of tourism when monitoring the impact of the BSPVES, and largely ignoring the need for and importance of two way A to B t ravel, protecting air services when air and surface transport compete against all other interstate routes and when surface travel is necessary for expanding the market for air, or for supporting football clubs.

Some of these outcomes may be necessary to boost an accommodation sector in Tasmania . They are not appropriate for a link connecting two broad- based state economies where most of the Gross State Product is derived from a variety of people related activities, not just from an accommodation sector.
In Tasmania's case, the trickledown impact from the accommodation sector is far too small to drive a whole economy.
It seems the Ministerial response has been written with little or no knowledge of the Coalition promises in 1996 and history, showing the extent of the support for equalisation across the nation.
It took a lot of effort to have the BSPVES introduced. The change made in 2001-2 was not similarly fought for, or supported.

From my experience, the Coalition parties or the nation would never have supported such a change in 1996, or in 2001-2, or even now, without the Commonwealth funding every remote tourist region, regardless of being separated by mountains, water or desert.
Certain, consistently priced, sea highway access for and to people is critical to our nation. Also for many people related activities across South Eastern Australia. Why destroy it?

The move away from interstate highway equalisation is doing major damage to large economies. Trillions are invested along the Hume corridor that could more effectively be used. Why allow a 'punt' operator to govern the use of such an important corridor.
It is critical that the BSPVES be run to transport people, in both directions, at least as effectively as TFES is run for freight.
There is an ongoing case for applying the BSPVES in a way that delivers a major interstate, national infrastructure transport link, as originally intended.

Ways of meeting other objectives relating to one-way targeted leisure holidays with a car, and largely unrelated to basic transport, should not continue to prevail without an interstate transport scheme first being established.

'Geographical' and, so called 'unique challenges for Tasmania' referred to in the Minister's response, many caused by lacking an interstate road or rail link, are able to be largely overcome by a ferry service operating as part of the National Highway.
Ferries operate as highways across the world.
In this context, Tasmania is no more unique than other regions - it's how Canberra treats access that separates our nation.
