The link, based on equalization, should be fixed first, before considering any need for special subsidies for Tasmania. Highway equalisation schemes are not subsidies. The BSPVES campaign was also not a grab for subsidies.
The BSPVES was to deliver 'equalisation' based on equity and transport equality. It was directed at removing or minimizing any claim of disadvantage. The main benefit should flow to the traveller.

Canberra has not met its obligations to the nation, as promised by the Coalition, nor acted consistently with the intent of federation, of 'linking the colonies' into a 'national integrated economy through the movement of both people and freight'.
BSPVES monitoring has been too narrow. It has largely ignored an assessment of regular A to B highway travel, in both directions.
With an intended offer by Prime Minister Howard of $50 foot passenger fares, rejected in 2001, it seems unlikely that the changes in 2001-2 could really reduce passenger fares and fill ferries?
Equalisation is and was the cornerstone of the Coalition platform in 1996. It works for freight, why not for the movement of people to connect two large service based economies?
The BSPVES should not be seen as a gravy train for special interests, over the national interest.

The campaign for Bass Strait transport equality was a people initiated campaign for national transport equity- why erode faith in democracy and continue to separate our nation? Why destroy a link that can boost the economy and impact positively on all Australians and many of our businesses on both sides of Bass Strait?
It is time some in Canberra respected the wishes of the people and supported the Coalition's well documented equalisation policy.
The decision made in 2001-2, possibly mainly on the run, was one that took little account of its ramifications across South Eastern Australia.
It seems pointless to continue to try to support the 2001-2 policy setting against the reasons for a sea highway connection.

The Ministerial response seems to dismiss the accuracy of the view that 'a campaign for Bass Strait interstate transport equality, supported by business in two states, has failed to deliver despite resulting in massive federal funding'. Well, a more comprehensive knowledge of history may prove this opinion correct. The national conference resolutions of the time of both Coalition parties should also be noted.

Who or what is influencing policy relating to Bass Strait, and why? Why is history being ignored? Governance in this case seems far from transparent. I suggest that the claim made in the fourth paragraph of the Ministerial response be compared with the 1996 Tasmania Package documentation, if the claim is doubted.

Passenger fares, set by a single operator, at a level of its own choosing, with perhaps more targeted value added objectives can hardly be said to be even likely to meaningfully reduce passenger fares when fares vary daily and there seems no effective benchmark.

It is time Tasmania recognized the gift that the writer, the original Committee for Bass Strait Transport equality, the National Sea Highway Committee, its supporters and Prime Ministers on both sides of politics gave to Tasmania in 1996. It was a full opportunity for Tasmania to be connected, as all other states. This gift should be valued, respected, used and not trashed.
Canberra needs to urgently hear the ongoing voice of those located in Tasmania still calling for transport equity.

The denial of fair interstate access is very serious. The solution is so very simple. It is time to improve the effectiveness of our democracy and economy, not erode it. Policies that favour one industry on one side of Bass Strait should not govern the only vital surface artery between two states and the artery between the two main islands of Australia.

The BSPVES was aimed at turning a water barrier into a vital Bass Strait connecting link. Transport across it needs to mesh with a National transport strategy, road infrastructure connectivity, and integrate the use of cross border assets. It is also vital for maintaining critical mass, the spreading of overheads, lowering prices, and increasing service delivery.

Without Canberra acting, Tasmanians now have no chance of being connected to the rest of the nation' s transport grid. Their main highway goes to nowhere. They are now to be denied affordable access to family and friends on the mainland.

Core promises to those in the Apple Isle have now become meaningless whilst the fruits of the people's labour have been denied them and given to others. What sort of impression does this give of fairness and the governance process?
The people should be given the National Highway they voted for.

We, and our then supporters, including TI Line, had great expectations that a sea based National Highway connection would have a dramatic impact on numbers crossing positively impacting on the 'economy of many regions of South Eastern Australia'.
It did, but now a very successful Coalition sea highway policy is no longer.
Is our nation now justified in feeling that we asked for 'bread, and Canberra, despite massive federal funding, has given us stones?'
Signed
by SenatorAbetz (from one citizen).
Petition received.

That the Senateâ€”

(a) notes that 18 September marks the five-year anniversary of the launch of the Abbott Coalition Government's Operation Sovereign Borders policy, a military-led operation designed to break people-smuggling activities â€“ principally originating from Indonesia â€“ with boat turnÂ­ backs and intelligence gathering;
(b) acknowledges the roles of policy co-author, and now senator, Jim Molan and the then Minister for Immigration, Mr Scott Morrison, in successfully implementing that policy; and
(c) affirms its strong support for the policy and continuing to protect Australia's borders. (generalbusinessnoticeofmotionno.1044)

Bernardi to move on the next day of sitting:

(b) further notes that the position of Race Discrimination Commissioner fell vacant in August 2018;

That the Senateâ€”
(a) notes that:

(i) increased immunisation of children, which is essential for protecting them against diseases including pneumonia, polio, rotavirus diarrhoea, meningococcal and measles, now saves the lives of 2 to 3 million children per year â€“ nevertheless, 1.5 million children still die each year globally from vaccine-preventable diseases,

(ii) in 2017, 85 per cent of children globally received the full course of the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccine, a key measure of vaccine coverage, however this left nearly 20 million children not covered by this vaccine,

(iii) globally, 85 per cent of children receive the polio vaccine, however gaps in polio vaccine coverage allow some children to contract the disease, with 15 cases in Afghanistan and Pakistan in 2018 so far,

(iv) Gavi, The Vaccine Alliance, to which Australia has been a consistent contributor, has supported the vaccination of more than 690 million children, and saved an estimated 9 million lives â€“ in December 2018, Gavi will hold a midÂ­-term review to assess what changes to its strategy are needed to achieve increased and equitable access to vaccines, and

(v) Australia also partners with the World Bank Group to support countries in Southeast Asia and the Pacific to strengthen immunisation systems and help ensure they are sustainably financed and managed;
(b) recognises that:

(i) Australia co-sponsored a resolution at the 2017 World Health Assembly to accelerate access to vaccines, calling for the extension of immunisation services beyond infancy, increasing domestic financing, and strengthening international cooperation to achieve global vaccination goals, and

(ii) funding to the Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), to which Australia contributes, is due to decline as polio nears eradication â€“ this funding covers one-fifth of the World Health Organization's (WHO) costs, and accounts for a high proportion of the health and vaccination workforce in several countries, and GPEI and WHO are undertaking transition planning to ensure that skilled staff and services remain in countries where polio has been eradicated; and

(i) participate in planning to accelerate progress in making vaccines available to all children, including through the Gavi mid-term review, and

Senator
Hanson to move on the next day of sitting:
That the Senateâ€”
(a) notes that:

(i) the dairy industry in Australia was de-regulated in 2000, and since that time milk production has fallen from 12 billion litres a year to 9.5 billion litres a year, while the population has increased from 19 million to 25 million people,
(ii) the number of dairy farms has declined in Queensland from around 1 500 to about 380,

(iii) Queensland dairy herds are now in immediate danger through a failure of the winter and summer seasonal crops, and the shortage of quality feed means it is likely that whole herds will be sent to the slaughterhouse and families destroyed,

(iv) the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) dairy inquiry report was handed down in April 2018, and found that an increase in the fresh milk price in supermarkets would not benefit dairy farmers, only the processors,
(v) none of the eight recommendations in the ACCC's report have been implemented by the Federal Government,

(vi) there is an immediate need to deal with the imbalance in bargaining power between dairy farmers and processors by legislating to make unfair contracts and, in particular, multi-year contracts (which bind farmers but not processors) unlawful because dairy farmers do not have the means to pursue these unfair contracts through the courts, and
(vii) it is a myth that milk prices are set by market forces because farm-gate prices for milk are set by processors, that are often foreign-owned; and
(b) calls on the Federal Government:
(i to provide immediate additional financial support to dairy farmers who cannot feed their herds,
(ii to implement all of the ACCC recommendations, and
(iii to regulate the price of milk per litre paid by processors to dairy farmers to ensure a viable dairy industry. (generalbusinessnoticeofmotionno.1049)

Senator
Patrick to move on the next day of sittingâ€”
(1) That the Senate notes that:

(a) on 21 August 2018, the Senate agreed to an order for the production of documents directed at the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Energy for documents relating to the grant of $444 million to the Great Barrier Reef Foundation (the Foundation), including documents demonstrating due diligence was carried out on the Foundation;

(b) on 10 September 2018, the duty minister tabled the index to a due diligence report prepared by the Australian Government Solicitor but did not table the body of the report, making a public interest immunity claim of legal professional privilege;

(c to the extent that the report fulfils a due diligence task, it cannot be characterised as legal advice and, therefore, cannot attract the privilege â€“ it is noted the document comprised largely information that is available online free of charge or for a nominal fee, such as company details, insolvency notice search results, media searches, ASIC personal name search results, and AUSTLII case searches;
(d) the Senate does not accept legal professional privilege as a basis for a claim of public interest immunity;

(e) in EganvChadwick, Chief Justice Spigelman held that "in performing its accountability function, the Legislative Council may require access to legal advice on the basis of which the Executive acted, or purported to act...access to such advice will be relevant in order to make an informed assessment of the justification for the Executive decision. In my opinion, access to legal advice is reasonably necessary for the exercise by the Legislative Council of its functions"; and
(f) as a country that upholds the rule of law, the Government must not rely on conventions, no matter how longstanding, that are contrary to established principles in law.
(2) The Senate does not accept the public interest immunity claim made by the then Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Energy

Senator Birmingham) in relation to the due diligence report prepared by the Australian Government Solicitor, and requires the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment to table the due diligence report, in accordance with the order for the production of documents agreed to by the Senate on 21 August 2018. (generalbusinessnoticeofmotionno.1050)

Senator WILLIAMS (New South Walesâ€”Nationals Whip in the Senate) (15:41): I give notice of my intention, at the giving of notices on the next sitting day, to withdraw business of the Senate notices of motion Nos. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 standing in my name for for 12 sitting days after today (14 November 2018), proposing the disallowance of (1) health insurance regulations 2018, (2) marine orders 501 national law amendment order 2018, (3) marine order 507 2018, (4) Remuneration Tribunal amendment regulations 2018 and (5) superannuation amendments instrument 2018.
Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (15:41): I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (8) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Customs Amendment (Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations Plus Implementation) Bill 2018
Customs Tariff Amendment (Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations Plus Implementation) Bill 2018
Social Services Legislation Amendment (Student Reform) Bill 2018
Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 2018.
I also table statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during these sittings and seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

The bills implement Australia's tariff commitments and obligations under the Rules of Origin and Trade in Goods Chapters in Pacific Agreement on Closer Economic Relations Plus (PACER Plus). The bills amend the CustomsAct1901 to define PACER Plus originating goods and the CustomsTariffAct1995 to provide preferential tariff rates for these goods in accordance with PACER Plus.

PACER Plus was signed by the governments of Australia, New Zealand, Cook Islands, Kiribati, Nauru, Niue, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga and Tuvalu on 14 June 2017. Vanuatu signed the agreement on 7 September 2017.

PACER Plus will enter into force 60 days after eight of the negotiating Parties notify the Depository that they have completed their domestic legal processes. For remaining negotiating Parties, PACER Plus will enter into force for that country 60 days after they notify the Depository.

PACER Plus has the potential to drive trade, investment and economic integration in the Pacific. Ratifying PACER Plus early will assist the other negotiating Parties in maintaining momentum in their domestic treaty approval processes so that PACER Plus can enter into force and its benefits be realised.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Home Affairs and
Minister for Immigration and Border Protection)

This bill will increase parental income cut-off for the Youth Allowance Regional Workforce 'Independence' Criteria and will provide additional certainty for regional and remote students about whether they will meet this parental income cut-off. This bill will also make minor technical legislative amendments.

The Government announced this measure as part of the 2018-19 Budget, with a scheduled commencement date of 1 January 2019. Passage prior to the end of the 2018 Spring sittings is required, to ensure that the measure can commence on 1 January 2019. If it is not passed by then, the measure will not be able to assist students in semester 1, 2019.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Social Services)

The bill would reinsert an inadvertently removed provision to offset pension overpayments from bereavement payments in one streamlined transaction. The amendment regularises the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) practice and does not change entitlements for veterans and families.

DVA already has legal authority to provide bereavement payments and legal authority to recover overpayments of income support pensions. What this Bill will do is to streamline these two transactions into one administrative transaction. This means that the Repatriation Commission would not need to disturb the family with additional interactions and raise a formal debt against the estate of the deceased during a difficult period for a grieving partner.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs has become aware that a provision that used to exist in the Veterans' EntitlementsAct1986 (VEA) that enabled the Repatriation Commission to reduce income support bereavement payments by income support overpayments made to a deceased was inadvertently removed.
The provision needs to be re-inserted into the VEA to provide legal certainty and authority to continue the practice of recovering the overpayment from a surviving partner's bereavement payment.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

Senator GRIFF (South Australia) (15:46): I move:
That the Senateâ€”
Â Â Â (a) notes that:

Â Â Â Â Â Â (i) the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) has an Adverse Experience Reporting Program (AERP) through which purported adverse effects from registered veterinary medicines and agricultural chemicals are reported,

Â Â Â Â Â Â (ii) while adverse events can be reported by anyone, which includes farmers, vets, animal owners and handlers, and state or territory authorities, however, holders of the registration or permit for a registered product are legally required to report adverse events,
Â Â Â Â Â Â (iii) the AERP provides annual reports which document these events,
Â Â Â Â Â Â (iv) these annual reports, in their current form, date from 2005 to 2013 and are publicly available on the APVMA website â€“ reports dating back to 1995 are also available on the website,
Â Â Â Â Â Â (v) since 2013, there have been no annual Adverse Experience annual reports published on the APVMA website, and

Â Â Â Â Â Â (vi) reporting, classification, assessment and action from these adverse events ensures the ongoing safety, quality and effectiveness of agricultural and veterinary products following their registration, and as an example of this, in the 2013 annual report the APVMA assessed, classified and took action when necessary, on 3733 adverse event reports from veterinary medicines, 50 adverse event reports from agricultural chemicals, and 135 reports related to human health adverse events; and

Â Â Â (b) orders that there be laid on the table, by the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, by 5 pm on 13 September 2018, all the Adverse Experience Reporting Program annual reports produced by the APVMA for the year 2014 and every year following, to date.
Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (15:46): I seek leave to make a short statement.
The PRESIDENT: Leave is granted for one minute.

Senator FIFIELD: The APVMA is in the final stages of accumulation and consolidation of data associated with the adverse experience reports for outstanding years. These will be progressively placed on the APVMA's website on a year-by-year basis over the next three months.
Question agreed to.
MOTIONS
Film Industry
Senator GRIFF (South Australia) (15:46): I move:
That the Senateâ€”
Â Â Â (a) celebrates the win by Australian film TheNightingale of the Special Jury Prize at the Venice Film Festival 2018;
Â Â Â (b) congratulates Indigenous Australian actor Baykali Ganambarr for winning the Marcello Mastroianni award for Best Young Actor at the Festival;

Â Â Â (c) recognises the support of Screen Australia, the ADL (Adelaide) Film Festival Fund, the SA Film Corporation and Screen Tasmania in the financing, production and post-production of TheNightingale;
Â Â Â (d) notes that:
Â Â Â (i) TheNightingale, by writer-director Ms Jennifer Kent, was the sole title in competition at the Venice Film Festival, which was directed by a woman,

Â Â Â (ii) according to Screen Australia, based on analysis of 217 feature films shot over the five years to June 2017, women accounted for 34% of the producers, 15% of the directors and 22% of the writers,

Â Â Â (iii) according to Screen Australia, as at April 2018, 31 features have been made since 1970 with an Indigenous Australian as director, producer, writer or director of photography â€“ 24 of these films were produced since 2000, compared to five in the 1990s, two in the 1980s and none at all in the 1970s,

Â Â Â (iv) in terms of the number of Indigenous Australian filmmakers, 22 individuals have worked on these 31 features: 11 credits have been as director, 14 as writer, five as producer and five as director of photography, with many of the same individuals credited in different roles, and
Â Â Â (v) it is important that Australian screen stories reflect the diversity of experiences and perspectives in contemporary Australian society; and
Â Â Â (e) calls on the Federal Government to:
Â Â Â (i) develop policies which support increased diversity within the Australian film industry in roles in front of, and behind the camera, and
Â Â Â (ii) reverse the funding cuts to Screen Australia amounting to $50 million over four years.
Senator FIFIELD (Victoriaâ€”Manager of Government Business in the Senate and Minister for Communications and the Arts) (15:47): I seek leave to make a short statement.
The PRESIDENT: Leave is granted for one minute.

Senator FIFIELD: The government is committed to a vibrant screen industry and notes the recent 25th anniversary of the Indigenous unit at Screen Australia and the success of the Gender Matters initiative. In addition to direct investment by Screen Australia in film and television, the Australian Film, Television and Radio School meets the future work needs of the industry. The sector also enjoyed special tax offsets under the Australian Screen Production Incentive, valued at $292 million in 2017-18. The Morrison government congratulates Jennifer Kent and other colleagues for their tremendous success at the Venice Film Festival.
Question agreed to.

Senator SIEWERT (Western Australiaâ€”Australian Greens Whip) (15:49): I, and also on behalf of Senators Polley, Lines and Hinch, move:
That the Senateâ€”
