Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matter in this subsection (see subsection 13.3(3) of the CriminalCode).
(10) Schedule 6, item 46, page 25 (lines 14 to 18), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the section, substitute:
(1) A person commits an offence if:
(a) proceedings (the PartVIIproceedings) are pending for the making of a parenting order to which this Subdivision applies in relation to a child; and
(b) the person takes or sends the child from Australia to a place outside Australia; and
(c) the child is not taken or sent from Australia to a place outside Australia:
Â Â Â (i) with the consent in writing (authenticated as prescribed) of each other party to the Part VII proceedings; or
Â Â Â (ii) in accordance with an order of a court made, under this Part or under a law of a State or Territory, after the institution of the Part VII proceedings; and
(d) the person is:
Â Â Â (i) a party to the Part VII proceedings; or
Â Â Â (ii) acting on behalf of, or at the request of, a person who is a party to the Part VII proceedings.
Note: The ancillary offence provisions of the CriminalCode, including section 11 (attempts), apply in relation to the offence created by this section.
Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 years.
(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if:

(a) the person (whether or not the person is the party to the Part VII proceedings) takes or sends the child from Australia to a place outside Australia because the person believes the conduct is necessary to prevent family violence; and
(b) the conduct is reasonable in the circumstances as the person perceives them.
Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matter in this subsection (see subsection 13.3(3) of the CriminalCode).
(11) Schedule 6, item 47, page 25 (line 24), before "A person", insert "(1)".
(12) Schedule 6, item 47, page 26 (lines 4 to 7), omit paragraph 65ZAA(c), substitute:

(c) the person retains the child outside Australia otherwise than in accordance with a consent or order of a kind mentioned in paragraph (b) (whether or not the person took or sent the child as mentioned in that paragraph); and
(13) Schedule 6, item 47, page 26 (after line 14), at the end of section 65ZAA, add:
(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if:

(a) the person (whether or not the person is the party to the Part VII proceedings) retains the child as mentioned in paragraph (1) (c) because the person believes the conduct is necessary to prevent family violence; and
(b) the conduct is reasonable in the circumstances as the person perceives them.
Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matter in this subsection (see subsection 13.3(3) of the CriminalCode).
(14) Schedule 6, page 26 (after line 14), after item 47, insert:
Repeal the subsections, substitute:
(1) A person (the firstperson) commits an offence if:
(a) a parenting order to which this Subdivision applies is in force in relation to a child; and
(b) the first person is a captain, owner or charterer of an aircraft or vessel; and
(c) another person (the carer) in whose favour the parenting order was made has served on the first person a statutory declaration that:
Â Â Â (i) relates to the parenting order; and
Â Â Â (ii) complies with subsection (4); and
(d) the statutory declaration was made by the carer not earlier than 7 days before the date of service; and
(e) the first person permits the child to leave a place in Australia in the aircraft or vessel; and
(f) the destination of the aircraft or vessel is outside Australia; and
(g) the child does not leave:
Â Â Â (i) in the company, or with the consent in writing (authenticated as prescribed), of the carer; or
Â Â Â (ii) in accordance with an order of a court made, under this Part or under a law of a State or Territory, at the time of, or after, the making of the parenting order.
Penalty: 60 penalty units.
(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if the first person has a reasonable excuse.
Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matter in subsection (2) (see subsection 13.3(3) of the CriminalCode).
Repeal the subsections, substitute:
(1) A person (the firstperson) commits an offence if:
(a) proceedings (the PartVIIproceedings) are pending for the making of a parenting order to which this Subdivision applies in relation to a child; and
(b) the first person is a captain, owner or charterer of an aircraft or vessel; and
(c) a party (the carer) to the Part VII proceedings has served on the captain, owner or charterer a statutory declaration that:
Â Â Â (i) relates to the Part VII proceedings; and
Â Â Â (ii) complies with subsection (4); and
(d) the statutory declaration was made by the carer not earlier than 7 days before the date of service; and
(e) the first person permits the child to leave a place in Australia in the aircraft or vessel; and
(f) the destination of the aircraft or vessel is outside Australia; and
(g) the child does not leave:
Â Â Â (i) in the company, or with the consent in writing (authenticated as prescribed), of the carer; or
Â Â Â (ii) in accordance with an order of a court made, under this Part or under a law of a State or Territory, after the institution of the Part VII proceedings.
Penalty: 60 penalty units.
(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if the first person has a reasonable excuse.
Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matter in subsection (2) (see subsection 13.3(3) of the CriminalCode).
Omit "65ZA(2) or 65ZB(2)", substitute "65ZA(1) or 65ZB(1)".
(15) Schedule 6, item 52, page 27 (lines 7 and 8), omit "sections 65Y, 65Z and", substitute "section".
(16) Schedule 6, page 27 (after line 8), after item 52, insert:

Regulations made for the purposes of paragraphs 65Y(2) (a), 65Z(2) (a), 65ZA(3) (a) and 65ZB(3) (a) of the FamilyLawAct1975 that are in force immediately before the commencement of this item are taken, after that commencement, to have been made for the purposes of subparagraphs 65Y(1) (c) (i), 65Z(1) (c) (i), 65ZA(1) (g) (i) and 65ZB(1) (g) (i) of that Act as amended by this Division.
(17) Schedule 8, page 38 (after line 17), after item 4, insert:
Repeal the heading, substitute:
We also oppose schedule 6 in the follow terms:
(3) Schedule 6, items 19 and 20, page 18 (lines 5 to 12), tobeopposed.

Senator FARRELL (South Australiaâ€”Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (18:42): In respect of these amendments, the Civil Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 2017 was introduced in March last year by the former Attorney-General under the former Prime Minister. In the long period since its introduction we in Labor have negotiated a number of amendments with the government to improve a number of measures in this bill and to clear up a number of minor inconsistencies and issues with drafting. Labor supports the amendments on sheet GJ134, all of which will improve the operation of the various acts that will be amended by this bill.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator McCarthy ) (18:43): The question is that the amendments (1), (2) and (4) to (17) on sheet GJ134 be agreed to.
Question agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: The question now is that items (19) and (20) of schedule 6 stand as printed.
Question negatived.
Senator LEYONHJELM (New South Wales) (18:45): by leaveâ€”I move amendments (1) to (4) on sheet 8205 together:
(1) Clause 2, page 2 (table item 11), omit "10", substitute "9".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (at the end of the table), add:
12. Schedule 10, Part 1
The day after this Act receives the Royal Assent.
Â
13. Schedule 10, Part 2
A single day to be fixed by Proclamation.
However, if the provisions do not commence within the period of 6 months beginning on the day this Act receives the Royal Assent, they commence on the day after the end of that period.
Â
(3) Schedule 10, page 51 (before line 4), before item 1, insert:
(4) Schedule 10, page 51 (after line 10), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Insert:

Nothing in Division 1 or 2 renders it unlawful for a person to discriminate against another person on the ground of the other person's sexual orientation, gender identity, intersex status, or marital or relationship status in the course of providing, or offering to provide, goods, services or facilities in connection with the solemnisation of a marriage under the MarriageAct1961.
Repeal the subsection.

These amendments seek to alter the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to ensure that those who provide or offer to provide goods, services or facilities in connection with the solemnisation of a marriage retain the right to do so on the grounds of the sexual orientation or relationship status of their would-be clients. This would provide an exemption from discrimination law not only for marriage celebrants but also for wedding planners, reception venue operators, florists and cake suppliers. It would assist those who wish to service same-sex marriages only and it would assist those who wish to service heterosexual marriages only.

The Liberal Democrats have always argued that the government has no business telling people they can't marry someone of the same sex, so we strongly supported legalisation of same-sex marriage. But, in addition, the Liberal Democrats have always argued that the government has no business telling people they must facilitate a same-sex marriage or, indeed, that they must facilitate a heterosexual marriage. Seeking freedom for one group at the price of denying it to another is not liberty, it is hypocrisy.

Now, can I point out: this is an issue of considerable significance to the Liberal Party and the conservative elements within the Labor Party. It is, indeed, a key issue to what's known as the 'Liberal base'. These are the concerns of that Liberal base which arose in the context of the same-sex marriage debate which were considered by the Ruddock inquiry, which the government is still to do anything with.

This amendment of mine was circulated well over a year ago so that there was no possibility that the government could say, 'Oh, we haven't had time to consider it.' There is no possibility that the government can say, 'Well, it hasn't gone to our party room.' The question, of course, is, 'Why didn't it go to the party room, if that's where it needed to go?' I'm pretty confident that, if it had gone to the party room, the party room would have said: 'Hell yes! Let's support this. This solves one of our main concerns.' The question then is: if not now, for this kind of amendment for the government to support, then when? If not now, then when? I intend to call a division on this. I commend my amendment to the Senate.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (18:49): The government does not support the amendments moved by Senator Leyonhjelm. The issue of religious protections in connection with the provision of goods and services for the solemnisation of marriage was canvassed in significant detail during the debate on marriage equality last year. This bill is not the appropriate forum for reopening this debate. On Friday, 18 May 2018, the then Prime Minister received the final report into religious freedom from the expert panel chaired by the Hon. Phillip Ruddock. The government is considering the report.
Senator FARRELL (South Australiaâ€”Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (18:49): I thank Senator Leyonhjelm for his contribution. However, the opposition will oppose this amendment.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator McCarthy ): The question is that amendments (1) to (4) on sheet 8205 be agreed to.
Â

body.p:
The committee divided. [18:54]
(The Temporary Chairâ€”Senator McCarthy)

p.span: Senator ANNING (Queensland) (18:56): We oppose schedule 10 in the following terms:
(2) Schedule 10, page 51 (lines 1 to 10), to be opposed.

In opposing this part of the Civil Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 2017, we aim to preserve the exemption of the Australian Defence Force from the Sexual Discrimination Act 1984. For good reason, this exemption has been in place since the act first passed into law in 1984. Currently, this bill seeks to repeal section 43 of the Sexual Discrimination Act, which would make discrimination against women in connection with employment in, engagement to or appointment to an Australian Defence Force position involving combat duties unlawful. Adopting Greens' policy, the Turnbull-Morrison government decided to remove the gender restrictions from ADF combat roles from 1 January 2016, regardless of the adverse impact of this on military capability. This bill seeks to bind future governments to the same policy and to compel military commanders to disregard gender as a criterion for selection of soldiers for physically demanding combat roles. Such a move can only compromise the capability of our military forces and our collective will as a nation to defend ourselves.

Firstly, I question whether, in the event of a major war, our country is ready for the very confronting and disturbing truth that many of our young girls will be sent to fight and die in the front lines. I question whether mums an dads at home are readyâ€”

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator McCarthy ): Senator Anning, just resume your seat for a moment. Senators, can I just remind you that there is a senator on his feet and I can hardly hear him.

Senator ANNING: I question whether mums and dads at home are ready for the stream of body bags filled with the mutilated remains of young girls cut down in the flower of their youth. How willing will this country be to confront hostile nations that threaten our nation and our way of life when this is the price? Or will the increased cost of war, made infinitely more terrible through the sacrifice of those who might have been the wives and mothers of the future, paralyse our national will and cause us to appease tyrants and military aggressors, to our enduring cost?

Secondly, the limitation of female service in the military has been in practice since time immemorial because of simple biology. The simple fact is that there are many jobs associated with combat that many women lack the physical attributes to undertake. No reasonable person would seek to deny women the right to do any job for which they are physically capable. But the inconvenient truth is that there are some jobs, including many involved in military combat roles, for which many women are physically unsuited.

However, this undeniable fact of biology does not conform to the socialist fantasy that anyone can do anything, that biology means nothing and that only environment shapes us. A favourite left-wing fantasy is the nonsense that men and women are somehow equally physically capable. Despite the biological differences between men and women that, regardless of environment, give rise to huge differences in upper body strength, physical endurance and aggression, the Left likes to pretend that biology makes no difference. Those of us who have served in the military are well aware of the significant deficiencies in the field performance of some women. Genetic factors define us and are the basis of both our strengths and our weaknesses. As a result of this, women are much better at many things than men, and men are better at some things than women.

In a broader social context, physical capability is an issue that has been taken seriously by a number of peak sporting bodies. Recently, footballer Hannah Mouncey was subjected to a litany of requests and requirements, including blood tests, to ensure that her physical capability did not overmatch that of the other competitors. Fallon Fox, an MMA fighter, beat to a bloody pulp a number of female opponents, entering the ring as a transgender fighter. There were howls of outrage due to the physical capabilities of both participants in their respective sports. Yet we are ignoring the same issue, not in a sporting context but in the defence of our nation.

This is not a matter of prejudice or environment; it is simply a function of biology. However, because the truth conflicts with the leftist ideological dogma, this irrefutable fact of nature is disregarded. Of course, I have no objection to people of equal ability being given equal opportunity in roles where their lack of strength, physical endurance and aggression makes no difference. I am all for women being treated equally in the military. However, combat service, particularly in the Army and the Navy, where strength really matters, is one area where the left-wing ideological dogma of physical equality of the sexes faces the harsh reality of truth. The left-wing Liberals in the Morrison government can joins hands with left-wing Labor and the Greens in pretending that the world is other than it is. But the truth really cannot be evaded, and trying to do so brings a significant cost.

In the Public Service, grim socialist determination to ensure equal responsibility of both genders simply sacrifices merit upon the altar of gender equality. This is unjust, but there is no significant detriment to the nation as a whole. However, in the military an effort to ensure that women achieve equal outcomes in areas where there is an explicit physical inequality of ability directly threatens operational capability. As a result of gender blindness, women are to be deliberately placed in roles that they may or may not be able to do. This is not only unfair to the better-qualified members who miss out as a result but is actually a threat to our nation's ability to defend itself.

So let us be clear what this section of the bill is about, because the Liberal-Nationals government, like Labor and the Greens, wants to pretend that everyone can do every job. If this bill passes without amendment, military commanders will be forced to employ women in jobs that they may not be able to do. I ask senators to support my amendment to keep in place the ADF exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and in so doing ensure that Australia's ability to defend itself will not be sacrificed in favour of political correctness.

talker.name: McCarthy, Sen Malarndirri (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator FARRELL (South Australiaâ€”Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (19:04): I thank Senator Anning for his explanation but indicate that the opposition will oppose the amendment.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (19:04): Senator Anning, the government will be opposing your amendment that seeks to oppose schedule 10 of the bill. The Australian government are deeply committed to gender equality and opposed to gender based discrimination. This is why we've proposed an amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to remove the ability for women to be discriminated against in connection with the ADF combat roles. The amendments would not have any impact on current ADF practice or policy. As of 1 January 2016, all gender restrictions have been removed from the ADF combat roles. This means that all women have an equal opportunity to apply and be considered for all ADF positions. This minor legislative amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act will remove the combat duties exemption to ensure Australian law aligns with the government's policy position and the current ADF position. Consistent with these changes to domestic law and policy, the Australian government is also moving to withdraw its reservation to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women relating to the exclusion of women from combat duties.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Ketter ): The question is that schedule 10 stand as printed.
Â

body.p:
The committee divided. [19:10]
The Temporary Chairâ€”Senator Ketter

Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

p.span: Third Reading
Senator McKENZIE (Victoriaâ€”Deputy Leader of The Nationals and Minister for Regional Services, Sport, Local Government and Decentralisation) (19:14): I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Treasury Laws Amendment (Black Economy Taskforce Measures No. 1) Bill 2018

p.span: Treasury Laws Amendment (Black Economy Taskforce Measures No. 1) Bill 2018
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Senator CAMERON (New South Wales) (19:15): Labor supports the Treasury Laws Amendment (Black Economy Taskforce Measures No. 1) Bill 2018. I will discuss later the proposed amendment we will put forward. That amendment, however, does not alter the operation of the measures in this bill.

The bill reflects last year's budget announcement that the government would commit to two of the interim Black Economy Taskforce report's recommendations. Schedule 1 of this bill prohibits the production, distribution and possession of sales suppression tools in relation to a business's tax obligations, and prohibits the use of electronic sales suppression tools to keep tax records incorrectly. Transaction data recorded by modern points-of-sale systems are a key component of a business's sales and accounting systems, and are particularly important for tax audit purposes. However, this has led to the development of electronic sales suppression tools that facilitate tax evasion by suppressing or falsifying records of transactions resulting from these systems. Such concerns had been flagged in prebudget submissions, including by Chartered Accountants Australia & New Zealand.

Currently, the taxation law contains a variety of offences, as well as civil administrative penalties relating to record keeping and tax evasion. Although these offences may apply to entities that use electronic sales suppression software to keep records incorrectly, the government argues that the current maximum penalties for the offences are not high enough to reflect the seriousness of using a tool to misrepresent an entity's tax position. The manufacture of electronic sales suppression tools may already be captured by the Criminal Code. However, as the bill's explanatory memorandum notes, these provisions require an intention that the device will be used to commit an offence of forgery or only apply to Commonwealth documents. These requirements can be difficult to satisfy in the case of electronic sales suppression tools.

As such, the offences in the bill are strict liability offences, as are the administrative penalties. It will not be necessary to establish fault if a person has produced or supplied an electronic sales suppression tool or provided a service in relation to such a tool. Similarly, the offences do not require any knowledge about the intended or actual use of an electronic sales suppression tool. Entities and persons that would otherwise commit an offence, or are subject to administrative penalties in relation to the production, distribution or possession of an electronic sales suppression tool are entitled to a defence from the relevant offence if the purpose of their conduct is to prevent or deter tax evasion or enforce an existing law. Anyone relying on this defence bears the evidential burden in proving the purpose for which they undertook the relevant conduct. The measure is similar to laws introduced into comparable jurisdictions like Canada.

Schedule 2 of this bill requires entities providing courier or cleaning services that have an ABN to report information to the ATO about transactions that involve engaging other entities to undertake those courier or cleaning services for them. This is an extension of the existing taxable payments reporting system that currently covers the building and construction industry and other sectors at high risk of tax avoidance.

The former Labor government introduced the TPRS, which was introduced in the 2012-13 financial year. Labor is pleased to see the government embrace Labor's important tax integrity measures. When the TPRS began it required businesses in the building and construction industry to report payments they make to contractors for building and construction services to the ATO. Evidence suggests that this program has improved contractor tax complianceâ€”
Debate interrupted.
